title: NA
body: Is this check intended as an optimization to return earlier, or is there an actual problem being addressed? From my reading of the code without #554 uriP is not used directly in senml_json_serialize(), but is passed to uri_toString() and then json_findAndCheckData(). uri_toString() already has checks for uriP being non-null. It will set depthP (baseLevel in senml_json_serialize()) to URI_DEPTH_NONE and return 0. json_findAndCheckData() will determine the desired level as URI_DEPTH_OBJECT and call prv_findAndCheckData(). With URI_DEPTH_OBJECT as the desired depth, prv_findAndCheckData() will return without using uriP.

title: Handle opened issues 🗃
body:
I did some clean-up in opened issue.

First I tried to define if opened issues are enhancement, bug or question and labelled  it in consequence.
For question, I tried to get some feedback from users and If I didn't get any answer after something like 1 month, I close and invite to reopen if needed.

**For old issue**, maybe the team should have a look, especially the ones which are labelled as "bug"  to see if bugs still exists or should be fixed. (But I guess this should be done after we merge all PR ? :thinking:)

**For recent issues**, it would be good if the team could answer in _"short"_ delay most of the time.
This shows that project is active and rewards user which takes time to give us feedback.
Generally there is not so much issue by days, so maybe taking few minutes by days is a good way and avoid to accumulate too many issues. I talked about answering not fixing or implementing  user request immediately. 
For easy to fix bug, being reactive could worth as those also show that project is really active and bring confidence.
Of course this is a open source project and so this is best effort and by the way I encourage to keep a rhythm that you could keep at long term.

@sbertin-telular, @rettichschnidi, @tuve, @qleisan Does it sounds good to you ? This is just advice so of course feel free to do as you can or prefer. :relaxed:

title: NA
body: Sounds good and my ambition is to be very active/responsive here. Putting a serious effort into specs and codebase to be able to deliver on that promise!

title: Bootstrap server example requires client TLV support
NA
body: I think this is only a temporary requirement until the changes to support LWM2M 1.1 for bootstrap are in place. I think the changes I have on https://github.com/sbertin-telular/wakaama/tree/bootstrap_format will eliminate the requirement once merged.

title: NA
body:
I suppose a bootstrap server should be able to handle LWM2M 1.0 and LWM2M 1.1 client.
So content format to use SHOULD probably depends on version used by the client.
AFAIK, the client does not send the LWM2M version on `Bootstrap Request` but in LWM2M 1.1 there is a new bootstrap parameter : `Preferred Content Format`.

So when this parameter is present that means that client is LWM2M 1.1 and by the way we know which content format to use.

The issue is this parameter is NOT required... So when client don't use it, we don't know if we face a LWM2M 1.0 or LWM2M 1.1 client...I suppose in this case the probability that we face either a "LWM2M 1.0" client or a "LWM2M 1.1 client which support TLV" is higher ans so we should use TLV ?
Or we need to begin bootstrap by a `Discover Request` ?

title: NA
NA
body: The specific commit is https://github.com/sbertin-telular/wakaama/commit/04e821972db2f5146b267f62cb8203bcc5a40156. For LWM2M 1.1 the client will always provide the ``Preferred Content Format``. The server will default to TLV if it does not support the ``Preferred Content Format`` from the client. An LWM2M 1.1 client that does not send the ``Preferred Content Format`` and does not support TLV would be a problem. Working around it would require processing the error response and trying a different format until one works. That would require quite a bit of additional logic.

title: NA
body:
I think this is a good behavior. :+1:

About,
> An LWM2M 1.1 client that does not send the Preferred Content Format and does not support TLV would be a problem.

I think a client which does not support TLV should seriously consider to use `prefered content format`. (I don't know why this is not mandatory?)
My Idea about using Discover Request does not help so much because there is no mandatory "multi value" Content format in LWM2M 1.1 ... (I just discover this reading the spec again)

```
The LwM2M Client MUST support plain text, opaque, and CoRE Link data formats and
 it SHOULD support at least one of SenML CBOR or SenML JSON data formats. 
```

So your idea about processing error response and trying a different format is probably the only way ? :thinking: 

In LWM2M 1.0 the server and the client MUST support TLV and TLV can be used for almost all needs. (single value, opaque, multi value) it seems to me this was really better for interoperability ? Now in LWM2M 1.1 it's more difficult to know which content format must be used by default ? I'm talking about bootstrap but also LWM2M server, or maybe I missed something ?

title: NA
body: In my opinion there is no need to introduce that additional logic now (or possibly never). Great that there is already a solution waiting for this bootstrap TLV issue.

title: If DATA is more than 1003 bytes only 1003 bytes are sent without any error message.
body:
While testing #461

server: write 0 /31024/10/5 DATA
client: dump /31024/10

If DATA is more than 1003 bytes only 1003 bytes are sent without any error message. Possibly command line input limitation.

title: NA
body: The examples have a #define for MAX_PACKET_SIZE that limits the input. for the bootstrap_server this is 198. For the others it is 1024.

title: NA
body: There is a truncation ("command line" or udp socket) for input longer than MAX_PACKET_SIZE. For the command line I guess this can be accepted but is there a potential interoperability issue when receiving packets from another lwm2m implementation?

title: NA
body:
[RFC7252 section 4.6](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7252#section-4.6) says:

    A CoAP message, appropriately encapsulated, SHOULD fit within a
    single IP packet (i.e., avoid IP fragmentation) and (by fitting into
    one UDP payload) obviously needs to fit within a single IP datagram.
    If the Path MTU is not known for a destination, an IP MTU of 1280
    bytes SHOULD be assumed; if nothing is known about the size of the
    headers, good upper bounds are 1152 bytes for the message size and
    1024 bytes for the payload size.

I think MAX_PACKET_SIZE applies to the entire message, so yes there is a potential interoperability issue for large messages.

title: NA
body:
Wakaama client/server examples use the `#define MAX_PACKET_SIZE` when receiving packets, silently truncating any packet that exceeds the limit. 
```
uint8_t buffer[MAX_PACKET_SIZE];
numBytes = recvfrom(data.sock, buffer, MAX_PACKET_SIZE, 0, (struct sockaddr *)&addr, &addrLen);
```
When sending packets the #define is not used and memory is allocated dynamically using malloc() allowing very large packets to be sent.
Hands on testing shows that
a) this is less of an issue with blocktransfer in place (packets are kept sufficiently small provided both parties support blocktransfer)
b) it is possible to send very large packets (if TLV is used, SENML has another limitation #526), but they are not accepted by the leshan server used.

Current best thinking (on my part) is to extend the receive buffer to `uint8_t buffer[MAX_PACKET_SIZE+1];` and check if this number of bytes is received the packet is dropped (better than corrupting data). 

Better yet would be to send appropriate coap response code...investigating...."Request Entity Too Large" ? @tuve any thoughts on this?

title: NA
body: I don't think 4.13 Enitity too large is appropriate since 4.xx errors indicates that the coap client made an errornous request,  which it did not. It is an  coap server error so the response should be 5.00 Internal server error. 4.13 actually reads Request Entity Too Large and it is not the request that is too large, it is the response.

title: NA
body:
Attempt to summarize the discussion so far
 > If DATA is more than 1003 bytes only 1003 bytes are sent without any error message. Possibly command line input limitation.

The title is misleading (I wrote it 😂). The concern is that the wakaama client and server truncate all **_received_** UDP payloads to MAX_PACKET_SIZE. There is also a truncation of command line input, arguably less of a concern.

Context matters, is it a request or a response that is being truncated, what format is being used. E.g. TLV might cause loss of information while SENML should cause parsing error and be detected. Blocktransfer should reduce the risk of this limit causing a problem.
No clear suggestion on how this should be addressed, if it needs to be. Dropping packets is easy, will prevent "corruption" in the TLV case mentioned but will prevent the "parsing error" detection if SENML.

title: NA
body: At that point I'm not sure a proper response can be constructed. It is unknown whether the packet is a request or response. I think it is reasonable to drop the packet at that point.

title: NA
body:
https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/issues/509#issuecomment-745387617 is a good hint to define the good default value for this buffer.

When we receive message larger than this buffer, the CoAP specification gives some good hint : 
>  If an implementation is too constrained to allow for allocating the
      above-mentioned upper bound, it could apply the following
      implementation strategy for messages not using DTLS security:
      Implementations receiving a datagram into a buffer that is too
      small are usually able to determine if the trailing portion of a
      datagram was discarded and to retrieve the initial portion.  So,
      at least the CoAP header and options, if not all of the payload,
      are likely to fit within the buffer.  A server can thus fully
      interpret a request and return a 4.13 (Request Entity Too Large;
      see Section 5.9.2.9) Response Code if the payload was truncated.
      A client sending an idempotent request and receiving a response
      larger than would fit in the buffer can repeat the request with a
      suitable value for the Block Option [BLOCK].
      
(at the end of https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7252#section-4.6)

Some ideas,  from an ideal world solution to the easier way : 
1. fallback to block transfer : for received request : use 4.13 + block option, for received response  : retry the request with block transfer
2. just notify issue : for received request : use 4.13, for received response : return error to the upper/application layer.
3. just ignore + logs

title: NA
body:
I don't know exactly where this buffer is used but note that if you are using DTLS you first need to decrypt the payload to be able to know if you face a response or a request. And so 1) or 2) could not work depending which buffer we are talking about.

About packet size negotiation with DTLS, you could be interested by : 
- https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6066#section-4
- Or more recent : https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8449

Maybe @boaks , you have some knowledge to share about this kind of question about CoAP and DTLS message size ?

title: NA
body: For C, I think, setup a "const" with the MAX_MESSAGE_SIZE and report a violation on the sending peer seems for me the best to do. To send a truncated messages seems for me to be unreliable (and somehow wasting bandwidth).

title: NA
body:
Increased MAX_PACKET_SIZE to 2048 (should be power of 2) and added logic to drop packet and print message if limit is exceeded. 
PR #532 
I consider this a pragmatic and clean solution...

title: NA
body:
> Increased MAX_PACKET_SIZE to 2048 (should be power of 2)

Where does the power of 2 requirement come from? I'm not objecting to it, I just want to understand it and have it documented.

title: NA
body:
_should_ was too strong. I googled and this was suggested in several threads. I think this is highly implementation/hardware dependent and might not make any difference. Some algorithms, memory managers, "hardware buffers" etc. work better with power of 2 sizes so maybe it can be considered good practice? :) 

Another concern was what would happen to the remaining data after a truncated packet is read from the socket. My understanding (and some practical tests) is that UDP sockets contrary to TCP discard the remaining bytes. If this is not true in all cases the "extra" packet should* be corrupt and discarded anyway.

*_here we go again_...

title: block transfer issues leshan <-> wakaama
body:
While testing #461 (block transfer)

Test with leshan server and wakaama client (leshan setting: multi-value: SENML_JSON, single-value: SENML-JSON)

"GUI write" to 31024/10/5 with ~200 bytes => "Request Entity Too Large" (leshan tries to use 512 byte block size?)

"GUI read" from 31024/10/5 with ~200 bytes => OK
128 byte block size used. (setup with "change /31024/10/5 <200bytes>")

"GUI read" from 31024/10/5 with 1024 bytes => "Internal server error"

title: NA
body:

We should investigate the reason of this (capture should help)
Californium should be able to handle this and adapt its blocksize.
(you can also change the prefered_block_size in Leshan, if you want to test if it works without size negotiation, in `californium.properties` if you run Leshan locally)

:+1:  (even for working one capture could be useful to see if standard is well respected)

"Internal server error" as response code sent by Wakaama, right ?

title: NA
body:
> Uploading a successful "GUI read" from 31024/10/5 with ~200 bytes => OK"

I looked at the capture and it looks OK.

> NB. copy&paste "change /31024/10/5 <200bytes>" to wakaama cli seems to fail sometimes/often. When read back with dump /31024/10 there might be garbage characters at the end. If that is the case it seems that leshan will not succeed to do GET

I'm not sure to get that point. :thinking: 

> Downloaded a newer version of leshan (github "Standalone Demos" "v2x"). There was no negotiation,

I tried to understand the capture. For now I see that **Wakaama** return a `4.13 Request Entity Too Large` with `Block Size: 128` but no negotiation was done. Currently this is not clear to me what is this "Block Size" option. I was expected something like `size1` option or `block1 szx`  option :thinking:  (need to investigate)

title: NA
body:
About negotiation, I looked at californium code and it expect : block1 option with szx.
In the capture wireshark display `Block Size: 128` which is not so clear but it seems the option type is **28** which is `Size2` option.
I think it's not OK as `Size2` is for response ( see https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7959#section-4)
If I correctly understand in this case Wakaama want to say to Leshan : "Please use a smaller block size"
Reading the spec, I think it should send `block1 with szx` (`size1` is for negotiation the whole payload size) : 
> Finally, a 4.13 response to a request with a Block1 Option (control
   usage, see Section 2.3) where the response carries a smaller SZX in
   its Block1 Option is a hint to try that smaller SZX.

(source : https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7959#section-2.9.3)
(About block1 negotiation see discussion : https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/tyEr_LY_jHquT3SqAIGQbi5P7dI/)

title: NA
body: I will have a look at this, the block 2 option shouldn't be set, it should be a size1 option.

title: NA
body:
@tuve, I think `size1` is not OK if you want to negotiate block size. (`size1` is for the whole payload size)

For block size negotiation, it should be `block1+szx`.

title: NA
body:
I was looking at this from rfc 7959 section 2.9.3

> also recommends that this response SHOULD include
> a Size1 Option (Section 4) to indicate the maximum size of request
> entity the server is able and willing to handle

title: NA
body:
Section 4 reads 

> Similarly, the Size1 Option may be used for two purposes:
> 
>    o  In a request carrying a Block1 Option, to indicate the current
>       estimate the client has of the total size of the resource
>       representation, measured in bytes ("size indication").
> 
>    o  In a 4.13 response, to indicate the maximum size that would have
>       been acceptable [RFC7252], measured in bytes.
> 

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7959#section-4

title: NA
body:
The specification is maybe a bit unclear but read : https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/tyEr_LY_jHquT3SqAIGQbi5P7dI/
which is clearer.
> I would expect that the server should send the desired block size if it wants the client to change from the block size it used, so 4.13 + Block1.  Size1 is not about block size, but about the size of the whole body - if the server has a limitation there, it might want to error out on a 4.13 (without a Block1 option).

title: NA
body:
So size 1 is about the whole payload (before we split it in block)
and block1+szx is to negotiation block size.

title: NA
body:
As I read the rfc 7959 the response should be 4.13 + size1, which in this context is "to indicate the maximum size that would have been acceptable [RFC7252], measured in bytes." as stated in section 4.

Now however the response is a size2 option which is clearly wrong.

title: NA
body: block1 + szx is appropriate if thee is 2.xx response I think

title: NA
body:
Let's try to see if we agree on the situation :slightly_smiling_face:.
Regarding https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/issues/510#issuecomment-740966671, Leshan is using block1+ szx 512 + size1 2078.

In this case, do we want to negotiate the whole payload or the block size ?

title: NA
body:
It is a actually the block size. I think the spec is a bit confusing but size1 has dual purpose. The normal way in a block transfer is to accept the block and respond with a block1 + szx to negotiate a different block size, however with a 4.13 the block is not accepted and the size 1 is the maximum size that can be handled. I guess this makes more sense (not as confusing) if there is no support for block transfer. However as I understand it we are not in a block transfer context here the client (leshan) has only sent a message without any block transfer.

Just saw you comment, that changes it bit

title: NA
body:
I agree if we are responding to a block1 with a 4.13 it should be block 1 + szx :) at least thats how I interpret (and I guess that was your point :D)

> Finally, a 4.13 response to a request with a Block1 Option (control
>    usage, see Section 2.3) where the response carries a smaller SZX in
>    its Block1 Option is a hint to try that smaller SZX. 

If there was not a block 1 request then it should be 4.13 + size 1, and then size 1 is a hint to retry with a block 1 where size 1 is the maximum handled (block) size. @sbernard31 do you agree with this?

title: NA
body:
> However as I understand it we are not in a block transfer context here the client (leshan) has only sent a message without any block transfer.

Nope, this is not the case. Here Leshan try to send a request (PUT) using block1 with block size 512.
We agree that we want to negotiate the block size. (this makes sense because https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/issues/510#issuecomment-740966671 confirm that if block size 128 was used this will work, I suppose there is a limited buffer size in wakaama which is OK)

My understanding of the specification is that wakaama should answer with a 4.13 with block1+szx 128.
This is confirmed by this mail : https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/tyEr_LY_jHquT3SqAIGQbi5P7dI/ from Carsten Bormann which is the author of the RFC.
> I would expect that the server should send the desired block size if it wants the client to change from the block size it used, so 4.13 + Block1. 

It also confirms that size1 is about the whole payload before we split it in block : 
>  Size1 is not about block size, but about the size of the whole body - if the server has a limitation there, it might want to error out on a 4.13 (without a Block1 option).

title: NA
body:
> I agree if we are responding to a block1 with a 4.13 it should be block 1 + szx 

We agree :relieved:  :+1: 

> If there was not a block 1 request then it should be 4.13 + size 1, and then size 1 is a hint to retry with a block 1 where size 1 is the maximum handled (block) size.

I think this is possible way and it was my understanding of the specification at the begining.
But as it sounded a bit silly to me because server should know the desired block size and so should ask for this size directly.
I finally asked [this](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/BfOlcS_BpNXbksfjzz6iGpEa_SQ/) to ietf **core** working group : 
> Now Imagine a client which sends a normal (not block1) request with 
a too large payload and server want this payload be sent by block1.
>  2) What exactly should send the server ? 4.13 or 4.13 + block1 with 
szx option ? is size1 should be used to guess the correct block size ?

And I get the [answer above](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/tyEr_LY_jHquT3SqAIGQbi5P7dI/) from Carsten which make me think that block1+szx could(should?) be used. (unless Carsten doesn't understand my question correctly :confused:)

title: NA
body: This was not how I read the rfc, but I must admit it makes more sense. Thanks for the clarifying links to your conversation with ieft core working group.  I will rework this with a 4.13 + block1 + szx under normal circumstances, and 4.13 + size1, only if the response really is too big and can't be handled.

title: NA
body:
@sbernard31 When I am serializing a block1 option I also need to set the m bit (more) and block num. None of these makes sense if we are not in a block1 context where we reply to a block 1 request. As far as I can tell these two are only discussed in the context of a 2.xx response. I also noted this in section 2.5 of the rfc 7959. 

The error code 4.13 (Request Entity Too Large) can be returned at any
time by a server that does not currently have the resources to store
blocks for a block-wise request payload transfer that it would intend
to implement in an atomic fashion.  (Note that a 4.13 response to a
request that does not employ Block1 is a hint for the client to try
sending Block1, and a 4.13 response with a smaller SZX in its Block1
Option than requested is a hint to try a smaller SZX.)

The first part is of course not what we discuss here, but the second part, even though it does not directly contradict what Carsten answered you, it does imply that a block 1 option is not part of the response if the request wasn't a a block1 request.

Maybe the response should be

- block 1 request: 4.13 + block1 option (num = 0 (mirrored from the request but it should be 0 as this only happens for the first reques i guess), m = true, prefered szx) 
- not a block 1 request: 4.13

As I interpret 7959 this would be the correct response, but the end result could be two consecutive 4.13 to make a successful transfer, first a 4.13 to hint a retry with block transfer and then a 4.13 + block 1 option to hint retry block transfer with a different szx.

I could of corse respond  4.13 + block1 option (num = 0, m = true, szx) to a non block transfer request, but I feel this is not right, there is no block option I am responding to and no block 0. Despite the incorrectness of block num 0, I actuallty think this is a better solution but I cant escape a nagging feeling that this is a deviation from what the rfc actually says.

Should we run this through ieft a second time to make sure we get it right?

title: NA
body:
Now I have sleept on it :). I will go with the 4.13 + block1 option (num = 0, m = 1 and szx = max block size) regardless if it is a block transfer or not.

I am still not convinced this is correct, in fact I still think it is not what the rfc says, but I understand this is what Carsten responded and how it is implemented californium.

If this turns out to be a missinterpretation I think a block1 option should not break anything and will likely be ignored by any coap client not expecting it in the response. So I will implement with the block1 option in a response but not expect it to be present in any response given (I will of course look for it and if present use it).

title: NA
body:
I understand your headache, I got pretty much the same one when I tried to implement this for californium. :sweat_smile: 

> When I am serializing a block1 option I also need to set the m bit (more) and block num. None of these makes sense if we are not in a block1 context where we reply to a block 1 request.

I think you should not worry too much about this, because we have pretty much the same thing with [pre-negotiation of block2](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7959#section-2.4). 
```
   To influence the block size used in a response, the requester MAY
   also use the Block2 Option on the initial request, giving the desired
   size, a block number of zero and an M bit of zero
```


> Should we run this through ieft a second time to make sure we get it right?

No problem to me if you want to get more clarification about that. But keep in mind that getting an answer is not guarantee or sometime takes a long time. So I don't advice to wait the answer to finish #461. (I mean I recommend we choose a solution and eventually we change it later, if needed)

> Now I have sleept on it :). I will go with the 4.13 + block1 option (num = 0, m = 1 and szx = max block size) regardless if it is a block transfer or not.

I think it's OK.

> If this turns out to be a missinterpretation I think a block1 option should not break anything and will likely be ignored by any coap client not expecting it in the response. So I will implement with the block1 option in a response but not expect it to be present in any response given (I will of course look for it and if present use it).

It makes sense.

> I am still not convinced this is correct, in fact I still think it is not what the rfc says, but I understand this is what Carsten responded and how it is implemented californium.

I agree it is not so clear ... 
I think you right to not accept easily to do something which seems to you "out of RFC". 
Unfortunately, in my experience, this is not the first time a RFC sounds not so clear to me. Sometime we even find thing which looks to contradiction (e.g. : https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/tls/rQ3El3ROKTN0rpzhRpJCaKOrUyU/)
So we need to deal with this ambiguity :disappointed:

title: The dataP pointer accesses an invalid address.
body:
lwm2m_dm_create() in core/management.c
```
...
    if (format != LWM2M_CONTENT_TLV
     && (size > 1 || dataP[0].type != LWM2M_TYPE_OBJECT_INSTANCE))
    {
        format = LWM2M_CONTENT_TLV;
...
```
When the `lwm2mserver` of the example is used, if you enter `create 0 /123 {}`. segmentation fault

title: NA
body:
I am able to reproduce the segmentation fault with your create command on the server example. The example server calls `lwm2m_dm_create()` with `dataP` set to `NULL` pointer (and `size` to -1) when it is unable to parse the input data like `{}`.

`dataP[0].type != LWM2M_TYPE_OBJECT_INSTANCE` then causes the segmentation fault.

My suggestions:
1. `dataP` should be checked before being accessed and if set to `NULL` the function should return `COAP_400_BAD_REQUEST`. (same for `size`)
2. `prv_create_client()` in lwm2mserver.c could also be adjusted to check for parsing errors earlier.

title: NA
body: I prefer 2) it is the parsing of command line input that fails (ie "syntax error") not a coap message error.

title: NA
body: I might need to revise my comment above. "{}" is legal when creating a new object? (not providing all/any resource information)

title: NA
body:
> "{}" is legal when creating a new object?

We are talking about SENML JSON OR OLD JSON content format right used for CREATE request?

Not so easy question. 
Mainly because create request target an object (not an object instance) and so if there is no record  we don't know the object instance ID to use for the new instance.
You could say that you let device choose the ID. This is what we do in Leshan, but recently I discover that letting device choose ID with those formats was not allowed ( (see https://github.com/OpenMobileAlliance/OMA_LwM2M_for_Developers/issues/422#issuecomment-747344840)), so I'm not sure Leshan implement the right behavior. 

Currently I would say this is not a valid payload and maybe Leshan should not allow this.

@qleisan, @sbertin-telular what do you think ?

title: NA
body:
The parsing of "{}" would be done in the server's prv_create_client function. This is independent of the format used for the CREATE request to the client. I don't think this function is even aware of what format will be used for the client communication. It can be SENML JSON, OLD JSON, or a simple integer for object ID 31024. The instance ID may be in the URI part of the command.

Hypothetically, a create with no resources could be valid if all resources are optional. I'm not sure what the usefulness of such an object would be, but we should probably allow the CREATE to go to the client if we can. At the least it could be useful for checking that the client would reject it when there is a single required resource.

title: NA
body:

You mean this is a dedicated format used for example command line ? (I guess it looks like OLD JSON  or something like this?)

> The instance ID may be in the URI part of the command.

I understand this is not allowed see ([transport§6.4.4-Device-Management-and-Service-Enablement-Interface](http://www.openmobilealliance.org/release/LightweightM2M/V1_1_1-20190617-A/HTML-Version/OMA-TS-LightweightM2M_Transport-V1_1_1-20190617-A.html#6-4-4-0-644-Device-Management-and-Service-Enablement-Interface)) 


Operation | CoAP Method and Content Formats | Path | Success | Failure
-- | -- | -- | -- | --
 Create | POST Content Format: SenML CBOR, SenML JSON, or TLV (see [LwM2M-CORE]) | **/{Object ID}** | 2.01 Created | 4.00 Bad Request, 4.01 Unauthorized, 4.04 Not Found, 4.05 Method Not Allowed, 4.06 Not Acceptable 

Unless again you talk about the URI of the command line ?

> Hypothetically, a create with no resources could be valid if all resources are optional

Only if format allow it and I'm not sure this is allowed for SENML JSON or OLD JSON for reason I exposed above but I could be wrong.

body:

Unless I missed something, I think you're right and we should : 
1. check inputs to avoid this kind of seg fault.
2. AND/OR clearly defined function contract (e.g. allowed value for function arguments)

Sometime 2) is enough but It could be less bug resilient and is not adapted when inputs come from "uncontrolled" source (like a foreign peer or a user)

title: NA
NA
body:
A little too naïve. That might handle this specific case, but we would need to check all the pointers passed in (except callback and userData) for NULL at the top of the function and return COAP_400_BAD_REQUEST if any are NULL.

I'm having second thoughts about checking all the inputs to lwm2m_* functions. It could increase the code size with little benefit over a clearly defined function contract. Code size is important if it is to be used on small embedded devices.

title: NA
body:
> I'm having second thoughts about checking all the inputs to lwm2m_* functions. It could increase the code size with little benefit over a clearly defined function contract. Code size is important if it is to be used on small embedded devices.

Just an Idea but maybe we could add a **#ifdef** which allow to keep or remove this inputs checks ?

title: NA
body:
`size = lwm2m_data_parse(&uri, ... , &dataP)` 
This function parses SENML/JSON/... and returns a list of length `size` of tree data structures `lwm2m_data_t`

- size > 0 indicate successful parsing e.g. `create 0 /123 [{"bn":"/123/","n":"6/2","v":69}]`
- size <= indicate unsuccessful parsing or contradicting URI information (including instance) e.g. </br> `create 0 /123 [{"bn":"/124/","n":"6/2","v":69}]`  or </br> `create 0 /123/7 [{"bn":"/123/","n":"6/2","v":69}]`. Other checks are also made.
- the tree (or list of trees) returned does not duplicate the `&uri` information e.g. </br>  `create 0 /123 [{"bn":"/123/","n":"6/2","v":69}]` creates a tree of depth 2 with a `LWM2M_TYPE_OBJECT_INSTANCE` node and a `LWM2M_TYPE_UNSIGNED_INTEGER` child node while </br> `create 0 /123/6 [{"bn":"/123/","n":"6/2","v":69}]` only creates a tree with a `LWM2M_TYPE_UNSIGNED_INTEGER` node

`prv_create_client(...)` use `lwm2m_data_parse()` and special handling of object 31024 to attempt to build a tree. 

I propose the code introduce a check here that returns an error if `size < 0`, this will however disqualify `create 0 /123 {}` as valid input, but it is not valid SENML/lwm2m JSON is it?

After this point the code checks if `&uri` contains instance information and if it does a new tree top node of type   `LWM2M_TYPE_OBJECT_INSTANCE` is created with the list of trees as children. 
Finally` lwm2m_dm_create()` is called.

title: NA
body:
> I propose the code introduce a check here that returns an error if `size < 0`, this will however disqualify `create 0 /123 {}` as valid input, but it is not valid SENML/lwm2m JSON is it?

Right now several formats could be vaild. SENML JSON, old JSOM, or just an integer for object 31024. If the check is after all the possible parsing, I'm good with that. I just don't want to fail with the first format tried.

Wakaama doesn't require or provide any specific IDE. It is a collection of C-files that can be imported to an IDE/editor of your choice.

You are mixing C and C++, this can get complicated. I pushed a commit `Demonstrate use of C++` to the same repo/branch as before `https://github.com/qleisan/wakaama.git` / `newTempObj ` that demonstrates how this can be done in a simple scenario. `cmake examples/client -B build-client`
`cd build-client`

`./lwm2mclient -4 -n client3303 -h leshan.eclipseprojects.io`

Go to [https://leshan.eclipseprojects.io/#/clients/client3303](https://leshan.eclipseprojects.io/#/clients/client3303) select "senml_json" in (single-value) dropdown. You should be able to click "Sensor Value" and get a (fake) reading back.
You should now also get a printout "_**Inside 'mycppfun()' C++ functionmycppfun() returned 26**_". This C++ function can be rewritten to read the sensor value using C++. 
Good luck!

title: Have separate request result and notify callbacks for lwm2m_observe
body:
Hi,
for the observe operation in the server, currently only one `lwm2m_result_callback_t` callback is used. It is called once for the result of the observe request, but then afterwards for each notify message. The arguments of the callback have different semantics depending when it was called.
For a successful "observe request result" the status is set to 0, but the subsequent notifies set the status field to the notify counter (COAP "Observe" option value).
Splitting this into two callbacks or having separate fields for status and the counter value would help here. 
Also, the counter value is not available in the request result, albeit it should be always 1.

There was also an earlier discussion in #379 around the same issue.

title: Client can be built with no supported formats
body: #520 brought up the issue and fixes it for the lightclient. A check should be added to liblwm2m.h to ensure a valid format is defined for any build. If no valid format is defined, it can produce an error with an appropriate message.

title: NA
body: (An OMA issue which seems about content format : https://github.com/OpenMobileAlliance/OMA_LwM2M_for_Developers/issues/514)

title: Internal Server Error caused by PRV_JSON_BUFFER_SIZE
body:
senml_json_serialize() has a buffer size PRV_JSON_BUFFER_SIZE set to 1024.

This causes "Internal Server Error" when doing GET on a larger resource using SENML_JSON. When using TLV (no longer default in the client) this is not a problem. Is this acceptable/according to spec?

Reported by @tuve in #461

title: NA
body:
Regarding [CoAP response code definition](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7252#section-5.9), I guess in this case INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR is the best choice.

Note eventually an error/diagnostic message can be added too : https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7252#section-5.5.2.

Maybe in this particular use case the issue is more that we are able to write a given payload but not to read it. In an ideal world all buffer sizes should be configured in a more consistent way. (Not sure if this is doable easily :sweat_smile:)

title: coap_get_packet_uri_as_string() possible buffer overrun
body: In er-coap-13.c the function coap_get_packet_uri_as_string() calls strncat() with the exact string length as intermediate stages constructing the string. This doesn't copy the NULL and may leave the string unterminated. Further appends to the string may end up past the end of the buffer.

title: NA
body: As I understand it strncat always null terminates even if n is less than string length of the copied string.

title: NA
body:
@tuve is correct. According to the man page, "As  with  strcat(),  the resulting string in dest is always null-terminated."

I was misled by the following compiler warning from gcc building the tests:
```
In file included from /usr/include/string.h:495,
                 from /home/sbertin/workspace/wakaama/coap/er-coap-13/er-coap-13.c:45:
In function ‘strncat’,
    inlined from ‘coap_get_packet_uri_as_string’ at /home/sbertin/workspace/wakaama/coap/er-coap-13/er-coap-13.c:413:9:
/usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/bits/string_fortified.h:136:10: warning: ‘__builtin_strncat’ output truncated before terminating nul copying as many bytes from a string as its length [-Wstringop-truncation]
  136 |   return __builtin___strncat_chk (__dest, __src, __len, __bos (__dest));
      |          ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/sbertin/workspace/wakaama/coap/er-coap-13/er-coap-13.c: In function ‘coap_get_packet_uri_as_string’:
/home/sbertin/workspace/wakaama/coap/er-coap-13/er-coap-13.c:390:23: note: length computed here
  390 |     size_t path_len = strlen(path_string);
      |                       ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In file included from /usr/include/string.h:495,
                 from /home/sbertin/workspace/wakaama/coap/er-coap-13/er-coap-13.c:45:
In function ‘strncat’,
    inlined from ‘coap_get_packet_uri_as_string’ at /home/sbertin/workspace/wakaama/coap/er-coap-13/er-coap-13.c:415:5:
/usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/bits/string_fortified.h:136:10: warning: ‘__builtin_strncat’ output truncated before terminating nul copying as many bytes from a string as its length [-Wstringop-truncation]
  136 |   return __builtin___strncat_chk (__dest, __src, __len, __bos (__dest));
      |          ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
/home/sbertin/workspace/wakaama/coap/er-coap-13/er-coap-13.c: In function ‘coap_get_packet_uri_as_string’:
/home/sbertin/workspace/wakaama/coap/er-coap-13/er-coap-13.c:392:24: note: length computed here
  392 |     size_t query_len = strlen(query_string);

https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2018/05/24/detecting-string-truncation-with-gcc-8/ describes this, search for the heading "Forming Truncated Strings with strncat" about 2/3rds down.

We are allocating a correctly sized buffer and filling it, so no real issue. I'm closing it.

title: Server example new connection memory leak
body:
The server example allocates a `connection_t` (48 bytes) for every new UDP connection. A new connection is identified by source IP (IPv6/IPv4) address and port combination a list. The `connection_t` list is only freed when the server terminates. Memory is allocated even before a valid CoAP packet was identified.

A long running server based on this implementation could run into serious memory problems or may be vulnerable to DOS attacks.

title: Endless loop when client responds with large payload without block transfer
body:
_Test scenario:_ A wakaama server issues a READ command to a client. 
When the client replies with a payload bigger than `REST_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE`, the wakaama server responds with "4.13 Entity too large" **and** advertises its configured block size with a new GET request and block2 option set. If the client does not handle the block2 GET correctly and again send a too large payload this results in an endless loop.
Ideas on how this can be handled, maybe a max retry count on the server side? I tested with wakaama server and zephyr lwm2m client.

title: NA
body:
>  A wakaama server issues a READ command to a client.
> When the client replies with a payload bigger than REST_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE, the wakaama server responds with "4.13 Entity too large"

We should not answer to a response with a response. You can not send a 4.13 in response to a 2.05.
I mean 4.13 is [client response code](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7252#section-5.9.2).
So there is maybe a first issue here. (or maybe I don't get you?)

> If the client does not handle the block2 GET correctly and again send a too large payload this results in an endless loop.

It sounds there is another issue here.

I guess this could be resolved like this.
- IF server receive a too big payload to a request sent **without block2** option THEN it could retry with block2 option.
- IF server receive a too big payload to a request sent **with block2** option THEN it should consider there is nothing to do and so report the error to application layer.

I guess this should avoid the infinite loop ? :thinking:

title: NA
body:
This screenshot illustrates a read command which shows the server behavior. (`REST_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE` is set to 512 on the server)
![zephyr_register_read_too_large](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17436433/107378788-989a3080-6aec-11eb-88f3-bc143ff39791.png)
This means the server should ignore the (too big) 2.05 response and only issue a new GET request with block2 set to `REST_MAX_CHUNK_SIZE`?

About your suggestions:
1. I agree, the server should indicate its block size with a second GET request.
2. If the client sends a block2 with a too big payload the server can still indicate its max. payload size with the block2 option. And hope the client can handle it correctly.

However after signaling its block size once, the server should stop trying and report an error.

title: NA
body:
> This screenshot illustrates a read command which shows the server behavior.

Generally this is better for analyzing to join the capture instead of a screenshot.

Looking at the screenshot, I see that I didn't understand your first point correctly.
The 4.13 is a response for the second GET request,  not a response for the 2.05 content response. So there is no issue here.

So it remains only the infinite GET issue.

@mlasch thx you very much for reporting this. :pray:

title: NA
body:
I just found out that I have to gzip the file in order to attach a pcap:
[zephyr_register_read_too_large.pcapng.gz](https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/files/5952329/zephyr_register_read_too_large.pcapng.gz)
The 4.13 has the same MID as the first GET and is a response to the the 2.05 response which also has the same MID. I agree its a bit messy in the screenshot.
`2001:db8::1` is the zephyr client, `2001:db8::2` is the wakaama server.

title: NA
body:
It's clearer with the capture, thx :pray:.
Sorry for confusion, but this change my understanding again about the first point :sweat_smile: ...
My first guess was right, there is an issue with the 4.13. It must not be send by the server when receiving a too big response. (unfortunately, I think there is no way in CoAP to inform the client in this case)

About the second point (infinite loop), 
Regarding the [RFC7959](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7959#section-2.4) :
> To influence the block size used in a response, the requester MAY
   also use the Block2 Option on the initial request, giving the desired
   size, a block number of zero and an M bit of zero. A _"CoAP"_ server (_"in our case LWM2M client"_) MUST use
   the block size indicated or a smaller size.
   
I think behavior defined in https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/issues/536#issuecomment-775965260 should be OK
- IF server receive a too big payload to a request sent without block2 option THEN it could retry with block2 option.
- IF server receive a too big payload to a request sent with block2 option THEN it should consider there is nothing to do and so report the error to application layer.

 If device can not use block2 option and payload is still too big, I think there is nothing more to do. This prevent infinite loop and avoid the need to add a new state (a kind of counter).

title: NA
body: I agree with the solution @sbernard31 outlined.

title: NA
body:
This will be fixed by #542, see
[zephyr-wakaama.pcap.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/files/6002759/zephyr-wakaama.pcap.zip)

title: NA
body: I am looking into rfc7252 about the response, when it is a piggyback response like this within an ack, it is clear that it should not be any  response back. However I am not entirely sure what to do if it is a separate response in a confirmable. Should we just ack that message regardless if we can handle it or not or is it ok to respond with an error code? I guess it is the first but I would like to hear your thought as well. @sbernard31 @mlasch

title: NA
body:
I'm not sure to get you. 

> Should we just ack that message regardless if we can handle it or not or is it ok to respond with an error code? I guess it is the first

This is my understanding. Just sending the ACK. The ACK just means I get your message (response or request) nothing else more. Seperate response does not change that we can not answer to a response with a response so if we can not handle it, we just ignore it. The Foreign peer will not be aware we can handle it.
(optional) Ideally Wakaama should raise to the upper layer that it received a response it is not able to handle.

title: NA
body:
I think rfc7959 is more clear on how to behave in different block-wise scenarios. In this case, example 3 in _3.1.  Block2 Examples_ shows how to handle a response when the server is not happy with the block size chosen by the client. In our case instead of sending an error to the client, the server should issue just a new GET with its preferred block size to the client. Also adjusting the block num accordingly.

(I'm using client/server in the lwm2m context, it's confusing with CoAP)

title: NA
body: The question is actually not related to blocktransfer. It is rather if the (lwm2m) server makes a GET request and the client responds with an ACK and a piggyback payload, then we can't respond with anything. However it is possible that the client responds with an empty ACK and then a confirmable (CON) message with the payload. The question is should we always ACK this CON or is it in this scenario possible to respond with an error code?

title: NA
body: When I think about it should be that we always ACK only, it is a response and not an request. We ACK that we have received it if there is any problem (like it is to large) it is up to the server to take appropriate action (like retrying the request as a block2).

title: Wakaama needs a more abstract API
body:
In order to simplify the usage and lower the entry barrier to Wakaama, I think the way of how to interact with library data structures should be reworked.
E.g. currently, on the server side, each implementation (examples and custom builds) have to handle the raw buffer. The buffer can contain all different content formats and parsing has to be implemented for each new application.
There is already the `lwm2m_data_t` structure in place which can hold IPSO objects independently of the content format in a tree structure. Also functions like `lwm2m_data_parse` and `lwm2m_data_serialize` are available. However they are a bit cumbersome to use, partly because in addition to the pointer to the structure there is also the size variable which have to be tracked. A clean interface would help a lot.

Some ideas:
* Modify the result callback to hide the raw buffer and do the parsing before the call (this assumes that all chunks of a block transfer can fit in memory):
```
typedef void (*lwm2m_result_callback_t) (uint16_t clientID, lwm2m_uri_t * uriP, int status, block_info_t * block_info, lwm2m_media_type_t format, uint8_t * data, int dataLength, void * userData);
```
<->
```
typedef void (*lwm2m_result_callback_t) (uint16_t clientID, lwm2m_uri_t * uriP, int status, block_info_t * block_info, lwm2m_data_t * lwm2m_data, int size, void * userData);
```
* Use a single structure which holds all important data like uri, parsed tree, size, status etc.
* As described in #521 the interface is already misused to report the notify counter via the status field.
* The callback should still allow access to the raw buffer if needed
  * If the chunks of a block transfer have to be treated individually
  * If parsing fails and custom parsing is needed
* It should be possible to disable the parsing (at build time?) due to memory concerns

This may imply major changes, so this issue is intended to collect and discuss ideas on how to improve the overall usability. Any thoughts?

title: NA
body:
@sbertin-telular, @qleisan, @tuve do you think some of this idea makes sense ? 

@mlasch if dev team agree with some of your ideas do you plan to contribute it or you just share the idea ?

title: NA
body: Yes definitely. The discussion should also cover how to interact more easily with objects on the client side from the "application".

title: NA
body:
On the client side one thing that would be helpful is to allow writes to be local or remote. Local writes might have more access. For example, assume a resource that holds the current temperature. This should be writable locally, but not remotely. Right now a separate function is needed to modify the value in the object when a new reading is made.

Taking it further, an abstract interface for objects in general might make implementing new objects easier. I'm thinking registering an object would also register the resources and types. Wakaama would handle storage of the values and notification back the the application of changes in values, attributes, etc. My concern with this would be needing extra flash and/or RAM on a device.

This allow us to know if write/read/exec is requested by  a Bootstrap or LWM2M server. The idea was also to be able to implement ACL later. We also have a "special" identity called SYSTEM which have all the right (like writing temperature).

title: Missing observations during firmware update
body:
_This issue is reported to me verbally I will investigate and update this issue description if needed. Sharing now to allow fast feedback from others_

During firmware update observed resource "state" might make quick transitions from Downloading->Downloaded->IDLE due to failed checksum check. It is expected that all states are reported to the server however this is not the case. 

[1.1.1 spec](https://www.openmobilealliance.org/release/LightweightM2M/V1_1_1-20190617-A/HTML-Version/OMA-TS-LightweightM2M_Core-V1_1_1-20190617-A.html) §5.1.2

> Notes: The Minimum Period Attribute indicates the minimum time in seconds the LwM2M Client MUST wait between two notifications. If a notification of an observed Resource is supposed to be generated but it is before pmin expiry, notification MUST be sent as soon as pmin expires. In the absence of this parameter, the Minimum Period is defined by the Default Minimum Period set in the LwM2M Server Account.

title: NA
body: Observes don't guarantee that all changes will be received by the server.

title: NA
body: But are they guaranteed to be sent or is it the latest available observation value that is sent when "pmin" expires? I.e. are they supposed to be queued so that (in this case) no state transition is lost (or rather not sent) due to fast transitions...?

title: NA
body:
The LWM2M 1.1.1 specification section 6.4.2 says "This operation includes the new value of the Object Instance or Resource."  My interpretation of the "new value" would be the value when the notify is sent, but I suppose depending on the resource and implementation notifies could be queued.

For a highly constrained device it may not be possible to queue values, so the latest would be sent. For a continuously changing resource, I would also expect the latest value to be sent as the queue may not drain as fast as it is filled. The latest value is generally the most relevant.

For Wakaama I would prefer to keep it simple and always report the latest value.

For the specific case of firmware update, the Update Result resource should be checked when a notification of an Idle State is received to see what happened. A timeout or polling read may also be needed in case notifications are lost.

title: NA
body:
If I correctly understand the issue.
This is about a LWM2M firmware update implementation at LWM2M server side based on observe to watch the state (/5/x/3) resource. 

Notification is just best effort to synchronize a resource between CoAP client and server meaning that :
 -  some notification can be lost.
  - notification order is not guarantee and CoAP client (LWM2M server in this case) implementation generally just drop older notification. (see [rfc7641#section-3.4](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7641#section-3.4))
  
> It is expected that all states are reported to the server however this is not the case.

So my understanding is that you can not rely on observe to receive all the state.
Observe can just be used as a kind of optimization to reduce latency but the implementation must be designed to work even if you never receive any notification.

In my experience  observation bring lot complexity and so I can imagine LWM2M device which does not support it and so this is another reason to not rely (exclusively?) on observe for firmware update.

> But are they guaranteed to be sent 

At LWM2M server side, we don't care if there are guaranteed to be sent as they are not guaranteed to be received :)

> or is it the latest available observation value that is sent when "pmin" expires? 

LWM2M pmin [is inspired](https://github.com/OpenMobileAlliance/OMA_LwM2M_for_Developers/issues/461#issuecomment-483554012) by [draft-ietf-core-dynlink-13#section-3.2.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-core-dynlink-13#section-3.2.1) and it says that : 
```
   When present, the minimum period indicates the minimum time, in
   seconds, between two consecutive notifications (whether or not the
   resource state has changed) ...
   A (CoAP) server MAY update the resource state with the last sampled value
   that occured during the pmin interval, after the pmin interval
   expires.
```
[The author described it like this](https://github.com/OpenMobileAlliance/OMA_LwM2M_for_Developers/issues/461#issuecomment-484158705) : 
_""Regardless of whether the value of the resource changes or not, do not send me its value any quicker than what I have specified for pmin"."_

And knowing that CoAP observation spirit is more about trying to sync the "most recent state" than caring about a "complete history" (see https://github.com/eclipse/leshan/wiki/LWM2M-Observe#the-spirit-of-observe-feature), I would say that this is the lastest available observation value. 

> I.e. are they supposed to be queued so that (in this case) no state transition is lost (or rather not sent) due to fast transitions...?

For reason exposed above, I think queuing it does not make so much sense.

I can see another problem with queuing it. Imagine a pmin set to 10s and the resource state change each 5s.
You can send only 1 notify each 10s but you will queue 2 value each 10s, it sounds not so good.

title: NA
body:
Thanks for your input, it has been useful. Summary of facts relevant to both wakaama and the discussion that initiated this issue are listed below. At this point it is not clear if there is a wakaama code related problem left to solve, I will keep this open some time to get feedback (share with additional people)

- packets can always be lost, server side needs to have a timeout/polling mechanism to deal with missing, out-of-order for key pieces of information e.g. firmware update state info. This is (of course) being worked on for the system discussed.
- to send a notification the client application must call `lwm2m_resource_value_changed()` and then `lwm2m_step()`.
- default behavior of the wakaama client/server is to send notifications immediately when `lwm2m_step()` is called. This can be altered by using pmin, pmax and other attributes
- default behavior of the wakaama client/server is to send non-confirmable coap messages for notify
- LwM2M **1.2** Core spec (5.1.2 Attributes Classification) allows for per resource control of confirmable/non-confirmable notify

title: NA
body:
Just some details about CON : 
Using CON instead of NON notify allow devices to be aware that notify are well received by the server.
But this does not resolved the reordering "issue". (relative to see [rfc7641#section-3.4](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7641#section-3.4))
I don't know if every body interpret the CoAP spec like Californium project but the current behavior of this CoAP stack is to ACK the too old notify and then just drop it. By dropping I mean that it is not returned to the application layer. 
(see https://github.com/eclipse/californium/blob/2.6.1/californium-core/src/main/java/org/eclipse/californium/core/coap/ClientObserveRelation.java#L328)

title: observe_setParameters  may cause dump
body:
if get a wrong msg，attrP->toSet be set to 0，we will get a dump in the last log api。

`LOG_ARG("Final toSet: %08X, minPeriod: %d, maxPeriod: %d, greaterThan: %f, lessThan: %f, step: %f",
            watcherP->parameters->toSet, watcherP->parameters->minPeriod, watcherP->parameters->maxPeriod, watcherP->parameters->greaterThan, watcherP->parameters->lessThan, watcherP->parameters->step);`
![wakaama](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20105247/110287188-0c165b80-8021-11eb-8336-570a751905a5.png)

title: NA
body: Thank you for reporting this. It does seem possible if the request is only clearing attributes with none set.

title: NA
body: Should I tag it as a bug ?

title: NA
body: Yes.

title: NA
body:
Can confirm that a server clear command to a client built with debug and not having any attributes set to that URI causes a crash.
e.g. 
`clear 0 /31024/10/1` => crash
while
`attr 0 /31024/10/1 40 60`
`clear 0 /31024/10/1` => no crash

title: NA
body:
#552 integrated in master. This should be fixed now. 

@lx121451  do not hesitate to reopen or comment if you found anything wrong ;)

title: bootstrap server answers a response with a response during block transfer
body:
Issue described in #549, wireshark logs included

Direct links to important comments
https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/pull/549#issuecomment-791279205
https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/pull/549#issuecomment-791310453

title: NA
body: #566 addresses the response answered with a response part. A new issue will be opened to to add blocktransfer support to bootstrap server.

title: Block transfer resend is ignored by client, halts transfer.
body:
https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/blob/c5c6d321d50ff0534a390acc2bd9db7de48da41d/coap/block.c#L181

Client side: When receiving a resend of a previously handled block, it is ignored. This halts the block transfer, since the server will keep re-sending the block and then give up.
Triggered when client response to block transfer message is lost (?).
Should instead return COAP_231_CONTINUE?

title: NA
body: Is it possible to provide a wireshark capture to be sure that we understand the issue correctly.

title: NA
body:
[210323_555_recreation_attempt.pcapng.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/files/6188131/210323_555_recreation_attempt.pcapng.zip)

> Client side: When receiving a resend of a previously handled block, it is ignored. This halts the block transfer, since the server will keep re-sending the block and then give up.
Triggered when client response to block transfer message is lost (?).

Attempted to recreate this issue without success, see attached wireshark log.
- client connects
- server writes data to client object, block transfer is triggered
- first client ACK (2.31) is dropped before it is processed by server (hack)
- server retransmits - everything works fine
- client disconnects

title: NA
body:
[210323_555_recreation_attempt_2.pcapng.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/files/6189016/210323_555_recreation_attempt_2.pcapng.zip)

New attempt after code inspection, this time drop ACK from second (not first) block transfer packet. Problem recreated!

title: A client which connects to a server intermittently can't deregister
body:
https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/blob/c5c6d321d50ff0534a390acc2bd9db7de48da41d/core/liblwm2m.c#L79

A client which connects to a server intermittently can't deregister without calling lwm2m_close. This requires the client to call lwm2m_init on each connection.
Should lwm2m_deregister be part of the interface for a client (include in liblwm2m.h)?

title: NA
body: I agree. It seems like an oversight in the API.

title: NA
NA
body: This looks good to me!

title: Segmentation Fault while remote Bootstrapping with Leshan
body:
During the Bootstrap Process with a remote Leshan Server I get the following on the Wakaama Client:

`-> State: STATE_BOOTSTRAPPING
[BOOTSTRAP] backup security and server objects
Sending 67 bytes to [***]:5784`  

......................

`decrypt_verify(): found 8 bytes cleartext
Segmentation fault`

The remote Leshan Bootstrap Server reports:

`ContentFormat [name=SENML_JSON, code=110]
2021-03-24 14:24:19,222 DEBUG DefaultBootstrapHandler$3 - Error for DefaultBootstrapSession [id=BMWfXnawRv, endpoint=lwm2m_ale, identity=Identity /***:49858[psk=***], authorized=true, contentFormat=ContentFormat [name=SENML_JSON, code=110], creationTime=1616595792969, request=org.eclipse.leshan.core.request.BootstrapRequest@4a0c2354, cancelled=false] while sending BootstrapDeleteRequest [/0]
org.eclipse.leshan.core.request.exception.TimeoutException: Request coap://***:49858/0 timed out : CoAP or blockwise timeout
        at org.eclipse.leshan.core.californium.CoapAsyncRequestObserver.onTimeout(CoapAsyncRequestObserver.java:119)
        at org.eclipse.californium.core.coap.Message.setTimedOut(Message.java:954)
        at org.eclipse.californium.core.coap.Request.setTimedOut(Request.java:1096)
        at org.eclipse.californium.core.network.Exchange.setTimedOut(Exchange.java:707)
        at org.eclipse.californium.core.network.stack.ReliabilityLayer$RetransmissionTask.retry(ReliabilityLayer.java:524)
        at org.eclipse.californium.core.network.stack.ReliabilityLayer$RetransmissionTask.access$200(ReliabilityLayer.java:430)
        at org.eclipse.californium.core.network.stack.ReliabilityLayer$RetransmissionTask$1.run(ReliabilityLayer.java:467)
        at org.eclipse.californium.elements.util.SerialExecutor$1.run(SerialExecutor.java:289)
        at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1128)
        at java.base/java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:628)
        at java.base/java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:834)`

I am using DTLS with PSK. Firewall settings are OK since the Leshan Client is able to connect in DTLS with Leshan Bootstrap Server and Server. The client runs on a RaspberryPi.

What am I missing?

Thank you in advance.

title: NA
body: Update: Connecting Wakaama and Leshan Servers with DTLS in localhost works with no issues

title: NA
body:
Update: it works by adding TLV format as described in [https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama](wakaama) before commit id: da234772f7a38a54e91c2b681f1c93360bc83a62

After that something seems to be broken when using DTLS PSK with a remote leshan bootstrap server with either TLV or SENML_JSON

[lwm2m_step:488] Final timeoutP: 60
[lwm2m_step:490] Final state: STATE_READY
 -> State: STATE_READY
```

title: Automatic code formatting
body:
Historically, the Wakaama code base did not use any kind of code formatting tools. Therefore, every file looks slightly different, making it more hard than necessary to read the code, figuring out and sticking to the predominant style.

Therefore, for C code I propose to pick clang-format (version 10 for now), using a code style close to the one LLVM, the creators of clang-format, use. Foreseeable adaptions might be:
- IndentWidth: 4 (instead of 2)
- ColumnLimit: 120 (instead of 80; current often oversteps the 80 characters boundary)

For CMake files, https://github.com/cheshirekow/cmake_format seems to be the tool to pick.

Acceptance criteria:
- Changes must be done in commits which are limited exclusively to cosmetic/style changes
- Above commit id(s) can be stored in a [--ignore-revs-file](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-blame#Documentation/git-blame.txt---ignore-revs-fileltfilegt) file (supported since Git 2.23).
- GitHub Action in place to prevent merging of non-formatted code
- Tools and exact versions to use defined
- Files in coap/er-coap-13 (and examples/shared/tinydtls) should not be touched
- <s>Code and comments checked for being garbled, exceptions in place where sensible</s> did not format the whole code base

Please note:
- This is issue complements #513

Any opinions on this?

title: NA
body:
I guess we definitely need something like this.  :+1: 

About tools to use and format rules, I let the team decide what best fits.

title: NA
body: I am really in favor of picking a standard like clang-format as suggested, as I do not see any real advantage in relation to the effort to maintain our own standard (or deviation from an existing standard).

title: NA
body: I'm in favor of adopting a code standard. No strong opinions on the specifics, what is suggested above works for me. Before any decision is made we should get input from @sbertin-telular also.

title: NA
body: I'm also in favor of a code standard with no strong opinions on the specifics. If it can easily be automated and enforced even better.

title: NA
body:
I tried different clang-format style definitions to approximate the style being used most often. However, always ended up with man thousands of line changes. And while using --ignore-revs-file would work for Git itself, many 3rd-party-tools (like SonarQube) do not support it, blaming me for all the issues... :/

Therefore, I implemented a partial solution for this issue: #595

It  enforces the code style on *new* code, which is far less intrusive than formatting all existing code. Would like to get some feedback on it.

title: NA
body:
This is in reference to https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/pull/602#issuecomment-836774135. It seems off topic there.

A pure cosmetic patch which reformats just the portion of code changed creates a burden on the developer. They need to make their changes to find out what needs reformatting, reformat, commit, and re-apply their changes. Repeat if more changes are requested in the pull request. Meanwhile unchanged code doesn't get the formatting updated. This could lead to a real mess. I'd rather see the code reformatted entirely (maybe 1 file per pull request to be more manageable) and move forward from there.

title: NA

```bash
git ls-files '*CMakeLists.txt' '*.cmake' | xargs cmake-lint
```

> This is in reference to [#602 (comment)](https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/pull/602#issuecomment-836774135). It seems off topic there.

> A pure cosmetic patch which reformats just the portion of code changed creates a burden on the developer. They need to make their changes to find out what needs reformatting, reformat, commit, and re-apply their changes. Repeat if more changes are requested in the pull request. Meanwhile unchanged code doesn't get the formatting updated. This could lead to a real mess. I'd rather see the code reformatted entirely (maybe 1 file per pull request to be more manageable) and move forward from there.

@sbertin-telular This will not happen for the CMake files.

body:
The current method (require new code do be properly formatted) actually requires (cosmetic) changes quite far apart from the actual code change. This either results in (too) noisy commits (a) or, when striving for separation of functional and cosmetic changes, requires a follow-up commit (b):
- https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/pull/685/commits/6b8d0fa0952bcd80f0801d6ab99464d4857853c1
- https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/pull/691/commits/e89761bb376ef2bede966a6b027464b1571cbcbb

(a) makes it hard to reason about and reviews contributions and (b) is not something we can seriously ask from any contributors IMHO.

Therefore, I can also to the conclusion that reformatting the entire code base is the way to go. I will create a PR shortly.

title: Copyright Headers: SPDX
body:
The copyright headers in our repository do not contain Software Package Data Exchange (SPDX) identifiers, which is required by the [Eclipse Foundation Project Handbook](https://www.eclipse.org/projects/handbook/#ip-copyright-headers).

# Acceptance Criteria
* All source code files have the following SPDX license identifier: `SPDX-License-Identifier: EPL-2.0 OR BSD-3-Clause`
* Used identifiers listed in NOTICE.md

title: NA
body:
SPDX in header sounds new to me, I guess I missed this requirement.

I'm not sure if we should use OR or AND but I think a [OR is more appropriated](https://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-2.0/faq.php#h.30qunqoq5upx) as I understand that user should accept the term of one of the license. :thinking: 

About EDL there is no SPDX Id and following this [message of Wayne](https://lists.spdx.org/g/Spdx-legal/message/2701) `BSD-3-Clause` should be used. 

So I understand it should be : 
``` 
SPDX-License-Identifier: EPL-2.0 OR BSD-3-Clause
```

@waynebeaton  could you confirm this ? :pray:

title: Git Commit Format
body:
The [Eclipse Foundation Project Handbook](https://www.eclipse.org/projects/handbook/#resources-commit) specifies how a Git commit must look like in order to be acceptable.

The following rule is mandatory, could be checked automatically but is currently now:
* Summary is max. 72 characters

The following rule is not mandatory ("should"), but when implementing the above as a checked in CI, I'd like to enforce it too:
* Existence of a description

title: NA
body: I will no write too much commit so this is clearly a decision on your side but I'm not sure making the description mandatory is a good idea. Sometime there is nothing much to say than just the summary.

title: NA
body:
I know Zephyr has this rule. While sometimes worked around (e.g. https://github.com/zephyrproject-rtos/zephyr/commit/22a82bc05432bd8db8dc1fe369d828150c80a2ee), it seems to me that such a rule encourages greatly to come up with helpful commit messages. 72 characters are most often not enough to describe the motivation behind a commit.

For example, most of the last 20 commit messages in https://github.com/zephyrproject-rtos/zephyr/commits/zephyr-v2.5.0 makes me feel like I have a shot at understand the commits intention thanks to the additional information in the body.

title: NA
body: From personal experience I can say, that being forced to write a description is sometimes annoying. However it forces yourself to think again about the commit. Also the workaround mentioned by @rettichschnidi works for small changes. I would support such a rule.

title: NA
body: Naming and explaining is usually the hardest part, but very important. I'm for (although I will regret it :)

title: Developer Documentation
body:
I (and [others too](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/65314279/cant-find-documentation-about-lwm2m-wakaama)) think Wakaama should work on offering great developer documentation in order to simplify on boarding of new developers, committers and improving the maintainability of the project.

For the technical part, my suggestion would be:
* Developer documentation: [Sphinx](https://www.sphinx-doc.org/)
  * Built for every commit, available as artifact
  * Most recent build for master deployed to https://www.eclipse.org/wakaama/ (or a subdirectory?)
* Source code: [Doxygen](https://www.doxygen.nl/)
  * Built for every commit, available as artifact
  * Most recent build for master deployed to https://www.eclipse.org/wakaama/doxygen (?)

Initial Content:
* Content of README.md (which needs to be reworked then to make sense again)
* examples/bootstrap_server/README
* Unsure if sensible: Landing page currently hosted at https://www.eclipse.org/wakaama/ (updated where necessary)
* Some examples for stuff we have already and will be discussing in the meantime.

The structure of the documentation I have no idea yet, but I think we can discuss this once the technical aspects have been agreed on and resolved (minus the deployment part).

What do you think?

title: NA
body: As we are adding static analyzing, linting etc as part of the ci I think we should document that as well and to what extent it is possible to perform checks locally before creating a pull request.

title: CI: Cover all defines
body:
Currently, we do not systematically ensure all our code is buildable for each define documented in README.md. For example, LWM2M_RAW_BLOCK1_REQUESTS is not set in any builds, allowing issues like #583 to slip in.

# Acceptance Criteria
* For all flags documented in README.md, the Wakaama source gets compiled and unit-tests executed with the flag enable and disabled at lest once.

# Non-Goal
* Building all possible combinations of compile time defines (too many combinations, waste of energy)

title: NA
body: See https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/pull/596#discussion_r620447382 for another reason why we need this.

title: NA
body:
Most of this is implemented by PR #646.

Missing:
- Unit testes are not yet getting built multiple times, but I am not entirely sure anymore this is actually needed.
- LWM2M_COAP_DEFAULT_BLOCK_SIZE not taken into account as it currently gets defined unconditionally by wakaama.cmake.

title: Run SonarCloud analysis on pull requests
body:
# Background 
Since PR #573 we are running SonarCloud analysis on branches in this repository. And only on those.

Analyzing PRs from forks is disabled due to security problems. See [SonarCloud analyses external PR](https://jira.sonarsource.com/browse/MMF-1371) and for details.

While secure, this leaves us with the chance of breaking master as it has happened for PR #590 and the resulting commit 8218ddcffedc0b549ddf8ef42b6e6e541985eb1b. 

# Goal
We should find a way so that we can (securely) enable PR scanning. [Keeping your GitHub Actions and workflows secure: Preventing pwn requests](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-preventing-pwn-requests/) seems to be a good starting point.

title: More badges
body:
PR #581 added one first badge to our readme.

I think we should have some more badges in order to motivate/attract more developers, improve the project overall.

Some badges I could find so far:
* SonarCloud:

    [![SonarCloud](https://sonarcloud.io/images/project_badges/sonarcloud-black.svg)](https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=eclipse_wakaama)
    [![SonarCloud](https://sonarcloud.io/images/project_badges/sonarcloud-orange.svg)](https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=eclipse_wakaama)
  * Metrics:

* [Shield.io](https://shields.io/)

  [![Closed PR](https://img.shields.io/github/issues-pr-closed/eclipse/wakaama)](https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama/pulls)
  ... and *many* more...

# Questions
* What do you think about the listed badges?
  * Clearly, the SonarCloud badges show that we have a lot to do (Wakaama code but also the SonarCloud configuration). Which of those (if any at all) would be helpful to give a good, fair impression of the project?
* What other badges would you like to see?

body: Can you make a proposal that we can look at? I think it is better to keep a "clean interface" and pick a small number of really useful badges to start with. Also be a bit selective so that we don't discourage anyone by posting bad looking metrics. We can add an issue to improve them first and the badge later when we want to maintain a good score.

In README.md, which gets rendered on the ["landing page"](https://github.com/eclipse/wakaama).

title: NA
body:
Welcome and thanks for your contribution!

However, we can not take contributions this way as we need to ensure that each contributor has agreed on the [Eclipse Contributor Agreement](https://www.eclipse.org/legal/ECA.php).

Can you please create a PR using this patch?

title: NA
body:
Welcome @jonathanpallant as @rettichschnidi mentioned we need a signed ECA.

Since we are lacking any decent "how to contribute" documentation, here is the quick crash course on how to contribute:

1, Sign the ECA
2, When you commit the patch to your forked repository, don't forget to sign the commit, all commits in a pull request mist be signed.
git commit --signoff --message "commit message" or git commit -s -m "commit message"

If you have any questions please let us know

title: NA
body:
> 2, When you commit the patch to your forked repository, don't forget to sign the commit, all commits in a pull request mist be signed.
> git commit --signoff --message "commit message" or git commit -s -m "commit message"

As learned via PR #590: [The `Signed-off-by` is not longer required by eclipse foundation](https://www.eclipse.org/lists/eclipse.org-committers/msg01291.html).
